{{redirect|ALSO||Also (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox training course | name = | synonyms = | pronounce = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | official_names = Advanced Life Support in Obstetrics | abbreviation = ALSO | type = | fiel = Medicine | specialty = Obstetrics | inventor = Dr. Damos and John W. Beasley M.D. | Development_date = 1991 | Ukraine date = | organizer = [[American Academy of Family Physicians]] | duration = 2 days | frequency = | participants = [[physicians]], certified [[nurse midwife|nurse midwives]] (CNM), [[OBGYN]] [[registered nurses]], and other health care providers | webcite = | related_course = | lbl1 = | dt1 = | lbl2 = | dt2 = | lbl3 = | dt3 = }} ''' Advanced Life Support in Obstetrics''' ('''ALSO''') is a program that was developed by the [[American Academy of Family Physicians]] (AAFP). This course helps [[physicians]], certified [[nurse midwife|nurse midwives]] (CNM), [[OBGYN]] [[registered nurses]], and other health care providers involved in potential emergencies in perinatal care of mothers. This course is important and even required in some hospitals for family practice physicians as well as a learning tool in most family practice residencies.<ref name=ALSO>[http://www.aafp.org/online/en/home/cme/aafpcourses/clinicalcourses/also/aboutalso.html About ALSO - Advanced Life Support in Obstetrics - American Academy of Family Physicians<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ALSO was developed at [[University of Wisconsin]] Department of [[Family Medicine]] by Dr. Damos and John W. Beasley M.D.<ref name=AFP>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3225/is_n3_v47/ai_13502156 Advanced life support in obstetrics course | American Family Physician | Find Articles at BNET<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
ALSO aims to decrease [[Disease#Morbidity|morbidity]] and [[Mortality rate|mortality]] for both the mother and baby. ALSO does this by incorporating both [[didactic]] and practical hands on workstations with lifelike mannequins.<ref>[http://www.also.net.au/whatis.html What is ALSO?<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719070100/http://www.also.net.au/whatis.html |date=July 19, 2008 }}</ref> Topics include assisted vaginal delivery, [[Doppler fetal monitor]]ing, fetal [[dystocia]]s, [[neonatal]] [[resuscitation]], management [[premature labor]], management of [[postpartum hemorrhage]], along with [[forceps]] and [[vacuum]]-assisted delivery. Participants must pass a written test as well as a practical hands-on case management of a birth (mega-delivery) incorporating many elements learned throughout the course.
ALSO helps serve the same function as [[advanced trauma life support]] (ATLS) and [[advanced cardiac life support]] (ACLS) to help keep physicians who work with rural or underserved populations up to date on [[evidence-based medicine]] and curriculum.<ref name=AFP/>

Roedy (Chairman of the Board)
Cindy Rachofsky (Vice Chairman)
Michael J. Klingensmith (Treasurer)
Arlen Andelson (Secretary)
| key_people = | main_organ = Board of Trustees | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | revenue = {{increase}}[[United States Dollar|$]]50,539,089 (2016){{cite web|title=2016 Annual Report|url=https://www.amfar.org/uploadedFiles/_amfarorg/About_amfAR/amfar_annualreport101117.pdf|publisher=amfAR|accessdate=10 November 2018}} | disbursements = | expenses = {{increase}}[[United States Dollar|$]]41,938,531 (2016) | endowment = [[United States Dollar|$]]80,773,661 (2016) | staff = | volunteers = | website = {{Official URL}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} '''The Foundation for AIDS Research (AmfAR)''' is an international [[Non-profit organization|nonprofit organization]] dedicated to the support of [[AIDS research]], [[HIV prevention]], treatment education, and the advocacy of AIDS-related public policy. amfAR is a tax-exempt corporation under Internal Revenue Code section [[501(c)(3) organization|501(c)(3)]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.kintera.org/site/lookup.asp?c=gmK3LlO1LnKaF&b=9289207&msource=0615ALTSEFB|title=Syringe Exchange Saves Lives and Money|access-date=2018-11-08}} and operates as an independent nonprofit with worldwide initiatives.{{Cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/globallink/|title=amfAR :: Around The World :: The Foundation for AIDS Research :: HIV / AIDS Research|website=www.amfar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}} amfAR was formed in New York City in September 1985 by [[Mathilde Krim|Dr. Mathilde Krim]], along with physician [[Joseph Sonnabend|Dr. Joseph Sonnabend]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.nypl.org/sites/default/files/archivalcollections/pdf/sonnabend.pdf|title=Joseph A. Sonnabend Papers|last=Karas|first=Laura|date=|website=The New York Public Library Humanities and Social Sciences Library Manuscripts and Archives Division|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} and activist [[Michael Callen]].{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130807120900/http://immunity.org.uk/videos.html|title=Immunity Resource Foundation - Meditel Film and Video Archive|date=2013-08-07|access-date=2018-10-26}} The organization originally began in April 1983 as the Krim-founded [[AIDS Medical Foundation|AIDS Medical Foundation (AMF)]], which sought to lessen the stigma surrounding HIV/AIDS diagnoses, as well as to increase funding to the cause. The name change came as a result of the AMF's merge with the California-based National AIDS Research Foundation,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/nyregion/painful-political-lesson-for-aids-crusader.html|title=Painful Political Lesson for AIDS Crusader|last=Carmody|first=Deirdre|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}} which sought to actively engage in HIV-related drug development.{{Cite book|title=And The Band Played On|last=Shilts|first=Randy|publisher=St. Martin's Press|year=1987|isbn=978-0-312-00994-6|location=London, England|pages=157}} What resulted was a foundation that prioritized both research and development as well as policy influence. This foundation was one of the first of its kind to embody both aspects of healthcare. amfAR currently has three headquarters, located in [[New York City]]; [[Washington, D.C.|Washington D.C.]]; and [[Bangkok|Bangkok, Thailand]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/contact/|title=amfAR :: Contact Us :: The Foundation for AIDS Research :: HIV / AIDS Research|website=www.amfar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}}amfAR spurs research and development through providing grants and fellowships to organizations, such as the Family Institute of Health, and individuals through the Mathilde Krim Fellowships in Basic Biomedical Research.{{Cite journal|date=2008-08-09|title=The history and challenge of HIV prevention|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140673608608843|journal=The Lancet|language=en|volume=372|issue=9637|pages=475–488|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(08)60884-3|pmid=18687461|issn=0140-6736|last1=Merson|first1=Michael H.|last2=O'Malley|first2=Jeffrey|last3=Serwadda|first3=David|last4=Apisuk|first4=Chantawipa}}{{Cite web|url=https://ocs.yale.edu/career-resource/amfar-allan-rosenfield-md-hiv|title=amfAR: Allan Rosenfield, M.D., HIV/AIDS Public Policy Internship and Fellowship program {{!}} Office of Career Strategy {{!}} Yale University|website=ocs.yale.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}} amfAR has provided over 3,300 grants to research teams across the world and has invested over $400 million to research aiming to effectively treat HIV and AIDS related illness.{{Cite web|url=https://www.campbellfoundation.net/amfar-grant-tripled|title=amFAR Grants Tripled {{!}} Fort Lauderdale {{!}} The Campbell Foundation|website=Funding AIDS/HIV research {{!}} Fort Lauderdale{{!}} The Campbell Foundation|language=en|access-date=2018-10-26}} amfAR's funds historically have gone to funding research, and as a result have helped pioneer community-based clinical research trials in the 1980s, as well as the involvement of AIDS patients in the drug approval process (''see also: [[Denver principles|Denver Principles]]'').{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Mathilde-Krim|title=Mathilde Krim {{!}} American medical researcher|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-10-26|language=en}} Changes in leadership have marked changes in focus, resulting in shifts from public health outreach (needle exchange program pushes){{Cite journal|last=Jarlais|first=Don C. Des|date=2006-07-13|title=Mathilde Krim, amfAR, and the Prevention of HIV Infection Among Injecting Drug Users: A Brief History|journal=AIDS Patient Care and STDs|language=en|volume=20|issue=7|pages=467–471|doi=10.1089/apc.2006.20.467|pmid=16839243|issn=1087-2914}} to public education (the amfAR AIDS Handbook){{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=v73UQy_V98kC&pg=PR11&dq=amfAR+AIDS+handbook#v=onepage&q=amfAR%20AIDS%20handbook&f=false|title=The AmfAR AIDS Handbook: The Complete Guide to Understanding HIV and AIDS|last=Ward|first=Darrell E.|last2=Krim|first2=Mathilde|date=1999|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|isbn=9780393316360|language=en}} to international research and outreach.{{Cite journal|last=Zhou|first=Jialun|last2=Dore|first2=Gregory J|last3=Zhang|first3=Fujie|last4=Lim|first4=Poh Lian|last5=Chen|first5=Yi-Ming A|date=2007-08-15|title=Hepatitis B and C virus coinfection in The TREAT Asia HIV Observational Database|journal=Journal of Gastroenterology and Hepatology|language=en|volume=22|issue=9|pages=1510–1518|doi=10.1111/j.1440-1746.2007.05062.x|pmid=17645479|issn=0815-9319}} amfAR has embarked on various national and international campaigns to spur AIDS/HIV research, create a dialogue and decrease stigma surrounding the disease. Through TREAT Asia and GMT, amfAR took international roots and began funding research and outreach on all inhabited continents.{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcaaids.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/RT_2011.pdf|title=U.S. and European Philanthropic Support to Address HIV/AIDS in 2011|last=Funders Concerned about AIDS|date=2011|website=European HIV/AIDS Funders|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 November 2018}} National initiatives have included the Countdown to a Cure for AIDS. The Institute for HIV Cures Research and amfAR Research Consortium on HIV Eradication (ARCHE) were both created to aid this countdown, both to help fund research as well as provide a facility at which those researcher can work.{{Cite web|url=http://ecor.mgh.harvard.edu/content/files/Funding/PrivateFundingOpps121616.pdf|title=PRIVATE FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES: DEC 16, 2016|last=Massachusetts General Hospital Corporate & Foundation Relations Office of Development|date=16 December 2016|website=Massachusetts General Hospital|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=7 November 2018}} To supplement the funding of these initiatives, amfAR is funded through sources like stock donations and their annual galas, which represent the majority of their source of funding.{{cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/uploadedFiles/_amfarorg/About_amfAR/amfAR-990-FY17-PUBLIC.pdf|title=Form 990 (2016)|website=amfAR Investors Relations|accessdate=10 November 2018}} After [[Kenneth Cole (designer)|Kenneth Cole]] stepped down as chairman, he was replaced by William H. Roedy. The current CEO Kevin Robert Frost joined amfAR in 1994 and became CEO in 2004.{{Cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/amfAR-Management-Team/|title=amfAR :: amfAR Management Team :: The Foundation for AIDS Research :: HIV / AIDS Research|website=www.amfar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}} Together they lead 9 members of the Management Team, 25 Board of Trustees members and over 100 advisors to both their scientific and political platforms.{{Cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/About-amfAR/Scientific-Advisory-Committee/|title=amfAR :: Scientific Advisory Committee :: The Foundation for AIDS Research :: HIV / AIDS Research|website=www.amfar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/About-amfAR/Program-Advisory-Council/|title=amfAR :: Program Advisory Council :: The Foundation for AIDS Research :: HIV / AIDS Research|website=www.amfar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}} [[Charity Watch]] rates Foundation for AIDS Research a "A-" grade.{{Cite web|url=https://www.charitywatch.org/ratings-and-metrics/foundation-for-aids-research-amfar/25|title=Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR) {{!}} Charity Ratings {{!}} America's Most Independent Charity Watchdog {{!}} CharityWatch|website=www.charitywatch.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-27}} [[Charity Navigator]] rates amfAR a four-star charity.{{Cite web|url=https://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=3254|title=Charity Navigator - Rating for amfAR|website=Charity Navigator|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}} ==History== === Origins === In the early 1980s, a group of researchers and scientists including [[Mathilde Krim]], Ph.D., then a researcher at New York's [[Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center]], formed an informal study group to investigate the condition that came to be known as AIDS. In 1983, Dr. Krim, Dr. [[Joseph Sonnabend]], [[Michael Callen]], and several others launched the New York-based AIDS Medical Foundation. In Los Angeles, Dr. [[Michael S. Gottlieb]] and amfAR Founding National Chairman Dame Elizabeth Taylor spearheaded the creation of the National AIDS Research Foundation. The two organizations merged in September 1985 to become "'''am'''erican '''f'''oundation for '''A'''IDS '''R'''esearch" (amfAR). The merged organization was launched with a $250,000 contribution from [[Rock Hudson]] shortly before his AIDS-related death in October 1985.{{Cite book|title=A Plague on All Our Houses|last=Hillman|first=Bruce|publisher=ForeEdge|year=2016|isbn=978-1611688757|location=Brandeis University|pages=154}} [[File:Mathilde Krim 1962.jpg|left|thumb|263x263px|Mathilde Krim in 1962, the year she departed Cornell Medical College]] === Leadership Under Krim === Krim's achievements during her time as the head of amfAR involved increased public education and direct political action. Primarily, Krim spearheaded the publishing of amfAR's first HIV/AIDS Treatment Directory, which provides medical professionals updated information on the treatment of HIV/AIDS, as well as clinical trials that [[People With AIDS|People with AIDS (PWAs)]] can participate in.{{Cite journal|date=2001-03-23|title=AmFAR HIV/AIDS treatment directory available|journal=AIDS Treatment News|issue=362|pages=8|issn=1052-4207|pmid=11569958}} The publishing of this directory continued for 11 volumes until the year 2001.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thebody.com/content/art31984.html|title=amfAR HIV/AIDS Treatment Directory Available|work=TheBody.com|access-date=2018-10-27}} Following the increased involvement of AIDS activists and patients with the drug approval process, Krim (along with [[Elizabeth Taylor]]) testified before the [[National Institutes of Health|National Institute of Health]] and Congress on the importance of clinical trials within community settings.{{Cite journal|last=Petricciani|first=John C.|date=1993|title=Global immunization against AIDS: economic considerations|journal=Vaccine|volume=11|issue=8|pages=873–877|doi=10.1016/0264-410x(93)90364-4|issn=0264-410X}} These testimonies and lobbying efforts by Krim led to the first [[Adult AIDS Clinical Trials Group]], which allowed people with AIDS and HIV to actively take part in the testing needed to approve AIDS drugs.{{Cite journal|date=1997-10-01|title=The relationship between study design, results, and reporting of randomized clinical trials of HIV infection|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0197245697000974|journal=Controlled Clinical Trials|language=en|volume=18|issue=5|pages=431–444|doi=10.1016/S0197-2456(97)00097-4|issn=0197-2456|last1=Ioannidis|first1=John P.A.|last2=Cappelleri|first2=Joseph C.|last3=Sacks|first3=Henry S.|last4=Lau|first4=Joseph}} Krim further shaped the structure of amfAR's fellowships, as she impelled the first grant of money to [[Peter Piot]] for his landmark study on female-to-male AIDS transmission in [[Kenya]].{{Cite book|title=HIV Prevention: A Comprehensive Approach|last=H. Mayer|first=Kenneth|publisher=Elsevier|year=2009|isbn=978-0-12-374235-3|location=London, England, United Kingdom|pages=169, 535}}
“They felt that this was a disease that resulted from a sleazy lifestyle, drugs or kinky sex — that certain people had learned their lesson and it served them right,” Dr. Krim told The New York Times Magazine in 1988. “That was the attitude, even on the part of respectable foundations that are supposed to be concerned about human welfare.”{{cite web|url=http://www.amfar.org/krim/|title=amfAR :: Dr. Mathilde Krim :: The Foundation for AIDS Research :: HIV / AIDS Research|website=Amfar.org|accessdate=21 September 2018}}
One of Krim's final projects was her push for [[Needle exchange programme|needle exchange programs]] in the face of mass stigma toward [[IV drug users|IV-drug users]]. Amid the 1980s [[War on drugs|"War on Drugs,"]] Krim's thoughts on sterile needle exchange is reflected in a quote, saying, "It was a brilliant idea. It would work—the drug users would use the clean needles—and it would be inexpensive.” Krim worked with the Outside In needle exchange program in Portland, Oregon in 1989, and funded trials of needle exchange programs in Tacoma, Washington between 1989-1991. amfAR used the results of these studies, as well as a study in [[New Haven, Connecticut|New Haven, CT]] to compile a report with the National Academy of Science which concluded that syringe exchange programs were safe and effective.{{Cite journal|last=Jones|first=T. Stephen|date=1997-04-03|title=Book Review Preventing HIV Transmission: The role of sterile needles and bleach Edited by Jacques Normand, David Vlahov, and Lincoln E. Moses. 334 pp. Washington, D.C., National Academy Press, 1995. $37.95. 0-309-05296-3|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|volume=336|issue=14|pages=1035–1036|doi=10.1056/nejm199704033361425|issn=0028-4793}} Before stepping down, Krim saw the international surge of amfAR, with the creation of initiatives such as TREAT Asia, and in 2004 the TREAT Asia HIV Observational Database (the only HIV database in Asia).{{Cite journal|last=Zhou|first=Jialun|last2=Kumarasamy|first2=N.|last3=Ditangco|first3=Rossana|last4=Kamarulzaman|first4=Adeeba|last5=Lee|first5=Christopher K. C.|last6=Li|first6=Patrick C. K.|last7=Paton|first7=Nicholas I.|last8=Phanuphak|first8=Praphan|last9=Pujari|first9=Sanjay|date=2005-2|title=The TREAT Asia HIV Observational Database |journal=Journal of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndromes (1999)|volume=38|issue=2|pages=174–179|doi=10.1097/01.qai.0000145351.96815.d5|issn=1525-4135| pmc = 3070962|pmid=15671802}} In 2005, Mathilde Krim stepped down as founding chair. According to amfAR, she served as CEO from 1990 through 2004, and is described as the "heart and soul" of the organization. Charles Kaiser described Krim as "determined to prevent America from using AIDS to stigmatize homosexuals" in his book ''The Gay Metropolis: The Landmark History of Gay Life in America''.{{Cite book|title=The Gay Metropolis: The Landmark History of Gay Life in America|last=Kaiser|first=Charles|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|year=1997|isbn=978-0802143174|location=New York, NY|pages=}} She was widely viewed as someone who fought on the front lines against prejudices against many people with AIDS. Apart from aiding research for life saving drugs, Krim was equally a proponent of reshaping public opinion, as noted by the [[The New York Times|New York Times]] tributes to her and those who interacted with her.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/16/obituaries/mathilde-krim-mobilizing-force-in-an-aids-crusade-dies-at-91.html|title=Mathilde Krim, Mobilizing Force in an AIDS Crusade, Dies at 91|access-date=2018-10-26|language=en}} === amfAR After Krim === The year after Krim stepped down in 2004, the CDC reported that 1,000,000 Americans were living with HIV/AIDS.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/statistics/overview/ataglance.html|title=HIV in the United States {{!}} Statistics Overview {{!}} Statistics Center {{!}} HIV/AIDS {{!}} CDC|date=2018-08-06|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-10-27}} In an effort to reduce the stigma surrounding HIV/AIDS, amfAR's new chairman [[Kenneth Cole (designer)|Kenneth Cole]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/01/fashion/thursdaystyles/from-kenneth-cole-a-new-solidarity.html|title=From Kenneth Cole, a New Solidarity|last=Wilson|first=Eric|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}} led amfAR to partner with [[Viacom|Viacom Inc.]] and the [[Kaiser Family Foundation]] to launch an initiative called KNOW HIV/AIDS.{{Cite news|url=https://khn.org/morning-breakout/dr00034096/|title=Kenneth Cole Launches New Public Service Campaign on World AIDS Day|date=2005-12-02|work=Kaiser Health News|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-US}} This program funded an AIDS awareness campaign titled, "We All Have AIDS,"{{Cite journal|last=Berwick|first=Donald|date=2002-01-26|title="We all have AIDS": case for reducing the cost of HIV drugs to zero|journal=BMJ (Clinical Research Ed.)|volume=324|issue=7331|pages=214–216|issn=0959-8138| pmc = 1122133|pmid=11809645}} which marked a more controversial tone in amfAR's new public strategy. In line with the launching of program initiatives, amfAR under [[Kenneth Cole (designer)|Kenneth Cole]] launched the TREAT Asia pediatric network{{Cite journal|last=Kariminia|first=Azar|last2=Chokephaibulkit|first2=Kulkanya|last3=Pang|first3=Joselyn|last4=Lumbiganon|first4=Pagakrong|last5=Hansudewechakul|first5=Rawiwan|last6=Amin|first6=Janaki|last7=Kumarasamy|first7=Nagalingeswaran|last8=Puthanakit|first8=Thanyawee|last9=Kurniati|first9=Nia|date=2011-2|title=Cohort Profile: The TREAT Asia Pediatric HIV Observational Database |journal=International Journal of Epidemiology|volume=40|issue=1|pages=15–24|doi=10.1093/ije/dyp358|issn=0300-5771| pmc = 3106968|pmid=20100820}} and the MSM initiative, which was a global effort to help educate, treat and prevent HIV/AIDS in men who have sex with men.{{Cite journal|last=Clark|first=Hollie A.|last2=Oraka|first2=Emeka|last3=DiNenno|first3=Elizabeth A.|last4=Wesolowski|first4=Laura G.|last5=Chavez|first5=Pollyanna R.|last6=Pitasi|first6=Marc A.|last7=Delaney|first7=Kevin P.|date=2018-09-01|title=Men Who Have Sex with Men (MSM) Who Have Not Previously Tested for HIV: Results from the MSM Testing Initiative, United States (2012-2015)|journal=AIDS and Behavior|doi=10.1007/s10461-018-2266-3|issn=1573-3254|pmid=30173345}} In honor of its founding chair, amfAR launched the Mathilde Krim Fellowship in Basic Biomedical Research in 2008.{{Cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/krim-5-11-17/|title=amfAR :: Mathilde Krim Fellowships in Basic Biomedical Research :: The Foundation for AIDS Research :: HIV / AIDS Research|website=www.amfar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}} The goal of this fellowship is to spur young and independent research groups who are actively searching for HIV/AIDS medical advancements. This grant has spurred discoveries such as the first recorded birth of new HIV virus particles by Dr. Nolwenn Jouvenet, as well as other developments at the pinnacle of HIV research.{{Cite journal|last=Jouvenet|first=Nolwenn|date=February 2009|title=Broad-Spectrum Inhibition of Retroviral and Filoviral Particle Release by Tetherin|url=https://jvi.asm.org/content/jvi/83/4/1837.full.pdf|journal=Journal of Virology|volume=83,4|pages=1–8|via=Elsevier Science Direct}} Other recipients of the Mathilde Krim Fellowship such as Bing Chen{{Cite journal|last=Bing|first=E.G.|last2=Hays|first2=R.D.|last3=Jacobson|first3=L.P.|last4=Chen|first4=B.|last5=Gange|first5=S.J.|last6=Kass|first6=N.E.|last7=Chmiel|first7=J.S.|last8=Zucconi|first8=S.L.|date=2000|title=Health-related quality of life among people with HIV disease: Results from the Multicenter AIDS Cohort Study|journal=Quality of Life Research|language=en|volume=9|issue=1|pages=55–63|doi=10.1023/a:1008919227665|issn=0962-9343}} and Rosa Cardoso{{Cite journal|last=Pejchal|first=Robert|last2=Gach|first2=Johannes S.|last3=Brunel|first3=Florence M.|last4=Cardoso|first4=Rosa M.|last5=Stanfield|first5=Robyn L.|last6=Dawson|first6=Philip E.|last7=Burton|first7=Dennis R.|last8=Zwick|first8=Michael B.|last9=Wilson|first9=Ian A.|date=2009-09-01|title=A Conformational Switch in Human Immunodeficiency Virus gp41 Revealed by the Structures of Overlapping Epitopes Recognized by Neutralizing Antibodies|url=https://jvi.asm.org/content/83/17/8451|journal=Journal of Virology|language=en|volume=83|issue=17|pages=8451–8462|doi=10.1128/JVI.00685-09|issn=0022-538X|pmid=19515770|pmc=2738203}} have made discoveries that have been central to the modern understanding of the HIV virus.{{Cite web|url=https://quod.lib.umich.edu/c/cohenaids/5571095.0426.017?rgn=main;view=fulltext;q1=timelines++chronologies|title=Time Line|website=quod.lib.umich.edu|access-date=2018-10-27}} After Cole stepped down as chairman due to a fraud investigation surrounding money diversion,{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2018/02/08/kenneth-cole-resigns-amfar-chairman-following-harvey-weinstein-controversy/319180002/|title=Kenneth Cole resigns as amfAR chairman following Harvey Weinstein controversy|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}} he was replaced by William H. Roedy. The current CEO Kevin Robert Frost joined amfAR in 1994 and became CEO in 2004. Together they lead 9 members of the Management Team, 25 Board of Trustees members and over 100 advisors to both their scientific and political platforms. == Headquarters and Facilities == amfAR's Sheldon W. Andelson Public Policy Office is located in Washington D.C.,{{Cite web|url=http://lobby.la.psu.edu/020_Compulsory_Licensing/Organizational_Statements/AMFAR/AMFAR_Public_Policy.htm|title=Programs|website=lobby.la.psu.edu|access-date=2018-11-07}} and is where many Rosenfield public policy fellows{{Cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/On-the-Hill/Rosenfield-Fellowships/|title=amfAR :: Rosenfield Fellowships :: The Foundation for AIDS Research :: HIV / AIDS Research|website=www.amfar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}} and employees work, as well as its management team of CEO and Board of Trustees. amfAR's original headquarters as well as their largest operations facilities is in New York City. === Institute for HIV Cures Research === In 2015 amfAR announced a collaboration with the University of California San Francisco, Medical School to create their first Institute for HIV Cures Research.{{Cite web|url=https://ari.ucsf.edu/research/amfar-institute-hiv-cure-research|title=amfAR Institute for HIV Cure Research {{!}} AIDS Research Institute|website=ari.ucsf.edu|access-date=2018-11-07}} This facility works to foster research and was founded with the goal of finding a cure to AIDS by the year 2020.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/02/opinion/an-opening-in-the-war-against-aids.html|title=Opinion {{!}} An Opening in the War Against AIDS|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en}} The leaders of the institute are Paul Volberding, MD who is the head of the UCSF AIDS Research Institute; Satish Pillai, PhD who part of the Blood Systems Institute as well as Warner Greene, MD, PhD, who helps direct the program. To remark on the progress that the institute had been making since its foundation, Dr. Volberding told CBS News in 2016:
"To see the pace from the days that we could do very little other than watch our patients die to finding the first treatments and then working hard to make those treatments better to where we are now has been remarkable. We have a lot of different options of three or four drug combinations put together in a single pill that a person takes once a day. It's remarkably easier than it used to be."
=== Bangkok, Thailand Headquarters === amfAR established its first international headquarters in Klongtoey, Bangkok, Thailand in 2001 to accompany its TREAT Asia network.{{Cite web|url=https://www.iedea.org/regions/asia-pacific/|title=Asia-Pacific – IeDEA International epidemiology Databases to Evaluate AIDS|website=www.iedea.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-07}} The headquarters establishes closer contact to its 21 adult and 20 pediatric clinics in 12 countries across East Asia.{{Cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/treat-asia-network-sites/|title=amfAR :: TREAT Asia Network Sites :: The Foundation for AIDS Research :: HIV / AIDS Research|website=www.amfar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}} The headquarters is internationally run as well, and works to streamline the logistics of projects in TREAT Asia. Former Chairman Kenneth Cole announced that the decision to move headquarters to Thailand was due to the ability to use the government's generous resources that have been committed to treating the crisis, and have effectively reduced the HIV prevalence in the country to under 1.1% due to quick mobilization and dedicated work.{{Cite news|url=https://www.avert.org/professionals/hiv-around-world/asia-pacific/thailand|title=HIV and AIDS in Thailand|date=2015-07-21|work=AVERT|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en}} == Initiatives and Campaigns == With $20 million over five years, the amfAR Institute for HIV Cure Research will support the work of scientists at UC San Francisco (UCSF), the Gladstone Institute for Virology and Immunology (GIVI), the Blood Systems Research Institute (BSRI) and other academic partners who are at the forefront of the effort to cure AIDS, rather than simply treating it as a chronic disease. === National Initiatives === ==== Countdown to a Cure for AIDS ==== amfAR has long intended to find a scientific cure to AIDS by the year 2020, and it created the Countdown to a Cure for AIDS in February 2014 as a way of speeding up this process.{{Cite web|url=http://www.curecountdown.org/overview/|title=Overview|website=Countdown to a Cure for AIDS|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-07}} The "Countdown" is an investment initiative that intends to give $100 million to scientists working to find a cure. Most grants are given through applications at the University of California, San Francisco. By the year 2017, amfAR had granted $42 million to researchers, and it gave over $3.5 million in grants to six research teams under the amfAR Research Consortium on HIV Eradication (ARCHE), and later $1.2 million to AIDS innovators.{{Cite web|url=https://aumag.org/2017/10/16/novel-cure-research-supported-by-amfar/|title=Novel Cure Research Supported by amfAR {{!}} A&U Magazine|last=Needle|first=Chael|website=aumag.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-07}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.treatmentactiongroup.org/CURE/research-projects-funding|title=Research Projects & Funding {{!}} Treatment Action Group|last=|first=|date=|website=www.treatmentactiongroup.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-07}} By 2016, the Countdown, along with ARCHE had granted money to 139 principal investigators and key personnel across 16 states and 9 countries. the amfAR Institute for HIV Cure Research at the University of California, San Francisco began in 2015 as the central facility to achieve their Countdown to a Cure for AIDS by 2020. It began from a $20 million grant to UCSF. Many researchers who receive fellowships and grants from amfAR and ARCHE work at the new facilities at UCSF.{{Cite web|url=https://ari.ucsf.edu/research/scientists-frontline-cure-research|title=Scientists on the frontline of cure research {{!}} AIDS Research Institute|website=ari.ucsf.edu|access-date=2018-11-07}} Under the Countdown to a Cure for AIDS, amfAR hosts an annual HIV Cure Summit, which aims to hear from voices in the research community on breakthroughs, as well as discuss discoveries that have motivated AIDS research, such as the breakthrough with the [[The Berlin Patient|Berlin patient]], who spurred the countdown in the first place.{{Cite journal|last=Brown|first=Timothy Ray|date=2015-01-01|title=I Am the Berlin Patient: A Personal Reflection |journal=AIDS Research and Human Retroviruses|volume=31|issue=1|pages=2–3|doi=10.1089/aid.2014.0224|issn=0889-2229| pmc = 4287108|pmid=25328084}} === Global Initiatives === ==== TREAT Asia ==== [[File:TREAT_Asia_amfAR.jpg|left|frameless|161x161px]] The Therapeutics Research, Education and AIDS Training (TREAT) in Asia was founded in 2001 under the leadership of [[Mathilde Krim]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/globalinitiatives.html|title=amfAR :: Global Initiatives :: The Foundation for AIDS Research :: HIV / AIDS Research|website=www.amfar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}} The initiative aimed to create communication networks among Asian countries who are aiming to treat HIV, using Thailand as a model and a central headquarters for the operation. TREAT Asia is directed by Annette Sohn of the University of California San Francisco, who is a principal investigator alongside Matthew Law of the Kirby Institute at the University of South Wales.{{Cite journal|last=Hansudewechakul|first=Rawiwan|last2=Sirisanthana|first2=Virat|last3=Kurniati|first3=Nia|last4=Puthanakit|first4=Thanyawee|last5=Lumbiganon|first5=Pagakrong|last6=Yusoff|first6=Nik Anti-H.I.V. Drugs|last=Altman|first=Lawrence K.|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en}} ==== The GMT Initiative ==== The GMT initiative is dedicated to providing HIV/AIDS assistance to men who have sex with men (MSM) and transgender people (which they term as the collective 'gay men and transgender (GMT)').{{Cite journal|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1107/s160057671801289x/ks5605sup1.pdf|title=The amfAR GMT Initiative Mentoring Model: Strengthening Organizational Capacity and Impact Through Local Expertise|journal=Journal of Applied Crystallography|volume=51|issue=6|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-07|doi=10.1107/s160057671801289x|year=2018|last1=Scardi|first1=Paolo|last2=Azanza Ricardo|first2=Cristy L.|last3=Perez-Demydenko|first3=Camilo|last4=Coelho|first4=Alan A.}} Unlike TREAT Asia, the GMT Initiative is truly global, with recent work in regarding their mentoring model in Paraguay, Thailand, Tajikistan and Kenya and Ukraine. The GMT Initiative further aims to spur outreach to low-income individuals by providing the amfAR HIV Scholars Program with the Center for LGBT Health Research at the University of Pittsburgh. Scholarship recipients from 2015 include individuals from South Africa, Pakistan and Belize.{{Cite web|url=https://pre.lgbthlres.pitt.edu/2015/05/04/amfars-gmt-initiative-supports-grassroots-organizations-that-respond-to-the-devastating-impact-of-hivaids/|title=Center for LGBT Health Research {{!}} amfAR's GMT Initiative supports grassroots organizations that respond to the devastating impact of HIV/AIDS|website=pre.lgbthlres.pitt.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}} The GMT Initiative aims to provide mentorship training to MSM and transgender individuals in countries with low access to AIDS support. It created a mentoring model that empowers 'GMT' to connect with younger individuals with HIV/AIDS in spite of a potential homophobic and stigmatized environment in the low and middle income countries that they service.{{Cite journal|last=Stall|first=Ron|last2=Egan|first2=James|last3=Kinsky|first3=Suzanne|last4=Coulter|first4=Robert|last5=Friedman|first5=M|last6=Matthews|first6=Derrick|last7=Klindera|first7=Kent|last8=Cowing|first8=Michael|date=2016-04-01|title=Overview of the University of Pittsburgh/amfAR Training Program in HIV Prevention Research for MSM and Male-to-Female Transgender Populations in Low- and Middle-Income Countries|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/299571826|journal=AIDS and Behavior|volume=20|issue=Suppl 3|pages=426–436|doi=10.1007/s10461-016-1382-1|pmid=27037548}} == Funding == [[File:Liza_Minnelli_and_Kenneth_Cole_at_amfAR.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Liza_Minnelli_and_Kenneth_Cole_at_amfAR.jpg|thumb|Liza Minnelli with Kenneth Cole at annual amfAR Gala in 2006]] As a [[501(c)(3) organization|501(c)(3)]], amfAR files an annual 990 Form to the IRS, which is publicly accessible. The following information is garnered from their 2017 filing: {| class="wikitable" |+amfAR 2017 Revenue sources !Source !Amount (in USD) !Difference from previous year (2016) |- |''Contributions and Grants'' |$50,842,378 |{{font color|red|-$7,967,828}} |- |''Investment Income'' |$1,434,528 |{{font color|green|+$325,634}} |- |''Program Service Revenue'' |$0 |$0 |- |'''Total:''' |$'''52,276,906''' |'''{{font color|red|-8,435,626}}''' |} === Contributions and Grants === {| class="wikitable sortable" |+Contribution and Grants Breakdown, 2017 !Source !Amount (in USD) |- |''Federated Campaigns'' |$267,404 |- |''Membership Dues'' |$0 |- |''Fundraising Events'' |$33,063,451 |- |''Government Grants'' |$11,546,419 |- |''All other gifts, grants'' ''and misc. contributions'' |$135,714 |- |'''Total:''' |'''$50,842,378''' |} === Worldwide amfAR Galas === amfAR's largest source of revenue comes from its fundraising events, large portions of that money comes from one of its annual charity event held at the [[Hôtel du Cap-Eden Roc|Hôtel du Cap-Eden-Roc]] in [[Antibes, France]] titled "amfAR's Annual Cinema Against AIDS."{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimdobson/2018/05/10/exclusive-extravagant-amfar-gala-auction-items-at-the-2018-cannes-film-festival/#16208e3f355f|title=Exclusive: Extravagant Celebrity amfAR Gala Auction Items At The 2018 Cannes Film Festival|last=Dobson|first=Jim|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-11-02|language=en}} The gala aims to raise money through auctioning items, as well as selling a limited number of tickets. Since the first amfAR gala, the charity has raised over $210 million to support AIDS research causes.{{Cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/malaysia/the-borneo-post-sabah/20180519/282905206211947|title=Star Power Dims at Post-Weinstein Cannes Aids Gala|last=Sabah|date=19 May 2018|website=The Borneo Post|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The most recent gala held in [[Cannes]] raised around $20 million at its 2016 gala, which is a marked decrease from the over $25 million it raised in the same 2016 and 2017 events.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/20/fashion/celebrities-raise-more-than-25-million-at-amfars-gala-in-cannes.html|title=Celebrities Raise More Than $25 Million at amfAR’s Gala in Cannes|access-date=2018-11-02|language=en}} It was speculated that this decrease in funding was due to both the absence of its largest donor [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations|Harvey Weinstein]], as well as the scandal surrounding the ousting of [[Kenneth Cole (designer)|Kenneth Cole]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-filmfestival-cannes-amfar/cannes-swankiest-party-goes-ahead-without-driving-force-weinstein-idUSKCN1II2TD|title=Cannes' swankiest party goes ahead without 'driving force' Weinstein|last=Pomeroy|first=Robin|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-11-02|language=en-US}} Celebrities frequently donate items to be auctioned off for the foundation, and past donors have included [[Uma Thurman]], [[Karlie Kloss]] and [[Milla Jovovich]], among others. welcomes donations in the forms of stocks and securities. Though they do not disclose the individual donors of stocks, they publish the figure of $1,295,049 on their 990 Form to represent the interest and amount they receive through donations of stock.{{Cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/stock/|title=amfAR :: Gifts of Stock :: The Foundation for AIDS Research :: HIV / AIDS Research|website=www.amfar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}} Further fluctuations in losses through investment and payments of investment income are accounted through the Net Gain row, indicating a net gain of $139,479 following external investments and payments. == Public Health Education and Outreach == === Syringe Exchange Programs === Krim's original view on needle exchange was largely affected by exposure through visits to foundational needle exchange programs:
On one visit, Mathilde met a clearly pregnant woman coming to exchange syringes. Mathilde was very upset. After the woman left the exchange, Mathilde spoke to the exchange worker. “That woman should be in treatment, not exchanging syringes.” “Yes,” the worker replied, “but the prenatal clinics do not accept drug addicts, and the drug abuse treatment programs do not accept pregnant women.” -Don C. Des Jarlais, Ph.D.
After interactions like these, Krim began work with the Outside In needle exchange program in Portland, Oregon beginning in 1989; this program was a service program for youth who had run away. Led by Kathy Oliver, amfAR helped gain insurance support for the program, and later compiled a report that showed the effectiveness of the study: needle discard rates in Portland neighborhoods decreased as a result of the study.{{Cite book|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK236650/|title=Behavioral and Community Impact of the Portland Syringe Exchange Program|last=Programs|first=National Research Council (US) and Institute of Medicine (US) Panel on Needle Exchange and Bleach Distribution|date=1994|publisher=National Academies Press (US)|language=en}} Krim later used amfAR's research funding apparatus to help David Purchase begin a needle and syringe exchange program in Tacoma, Washington. He used the money granted to analyze Tacoma's syringe exchange programs. Similarly to the results found in the Portland study, Purchase found that hepatitis B, C and HIV rates were much lower for users in Pierce County who exchanged their needles than those who did not. The study also found low HIV rates among women who use the exchange for IUD injections.{{Cite journal|last=Hagan|first=H|last2=Jarlais|first2=D C|last3=Friedman|first3=S R|last4=Purchase|first4=D|last5=Alter|first5=M J|date=1995-11|title=Reduced risk of hepatitis B and hepatitis C among injection drug users in the Tacoma syringe exchange program.|journal=American Journal of Public Health|language=en|volume=85|issue=11|pages=1531–1537|doi=10.2105/ajph.85.11.1531|pmc=1615682|issn=0090-0036}} === amfAR ''AIDS Handbook'' === The first AIDS handbook was published in 1999 as an effort to give a "comprehensive" and "concise" description of HIV/AIDS and methods of prevention. This 496-page book was intended for the general public,{{Cite web|url=https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/the-amfar-aids-handbook-darrell-e-ward/1113144166|title=The AmFAR AIDS Handbook: The Complete Guide to Understanding HIV and AIDS|last=Noble|first=Barnes &|website=Barnes & Noble|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}} as opposed to their ''HIV/AIDS Treatment Directory'' intended for medical professionals.{{Cite web|url=http://books.wwnorton.com/books/The-AmFAR-AIDS-Handbook/|title=The AmFAR AIDS Handbook {{!}} W. W. Norton & Company|website=books.wwnorton.com|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite journal|date=2001-03-23|title=AmFAR HIV/AIDS treatment directory available|journal=AIDS Treatment News|issue=362|pages=8|issn=1052-4207|pmid=11569958}}This book was used in a study{{Cite journal|last=Chandarana|first=Praful C.|last2=Conlon|first2=Patrick|last3=Noh|first3=Samuel|last4=Field|first4=Victoria A.|date=1990|title=The Impact of AIDS Education Among Elementary School Students|journal=Canadian Journal of Public Health / Revue Canadienne de Sante'e Publique|volume=81|issue=4|pages=285–289|jstor=41989908}} intended to see the effects of AIDS education on elementary education. The study found statistically significant increases in AIDS comprehension in students who were educated using the amfAR ''AIDS Handbook.'' The handbook stands as one of amfAR's attempts at public education for AIDS/HIV related topics.{{Cite book|title=The AIDS Handbook Revised: A Guide to the Prevention of AIDS and HIV|last=results|first=search|date=1995-05-15|publisher=Macmillan Education|isbn=9780333945766|edition=3rd|language=English}} === Trans Pacific Partnership Opposition === In May 2015 amfAR released a report showing that increases in intellectual property rights of pharmaceutical countries would drive up the price of some drugs that are desperately needed in the developing world, namely countries who rely on affordable [[antiretroviral drugs]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.amfar.org/uploadedFiles/_amfarorg/Articles/On_The_Hill/2015/IB_TPP_Brief_RC_050615.pdf|title=Trans-Pacific Partnership: Curbing Access to Medicines Now and in the Future|last=|first=|date=May 2015|website=American Foundation for AIDS Research|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=10 November 2018}} The group says that would hamper the global fight against AIDS (and other diseases) at an unsustainable rate. This report marked the first time that amfAR involved itself in economic policy that indirectly pertained to AIDS, and its rally against Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) reached national attention as a provision of the TPP that was traditionally seen to be benign.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/2015/5/11/8584025/tpp-amfar-aids-generics|title=A major AIDS research group says the TPP will make it harder to fight AIDS|work=Vox|access-date=2018-10-27}} ==Controversies== === Cole's Controversial Chairmanship === Kenneth Cole served as the amfAR chairman for 14-years and as a board member for a total of 30-years.{{Cite journal|last=Laurence|first=Jeffrey|date=2018-03-01|title=In Gratitude: Personal Memories of the Late Dr. Mathilde Krim (July 9, 1926–January 15, 2018)|journal=AIDS Patient Care and STDs|language=en|volume=32|issue=3|pages=81–83|doi=10.1089/apc.2018.29002.com|pmid=29436840|issn=1087-2914}} In 2015, following years of controversy, he stepped down and now has no involvement in the organization.{{Cite web|url=https://www.kennethcole.com/lgfg-making-aids-history.html|title=Making AIDS History|website=Kenneth Cole|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/02/nyregion/harvey-weinstein-amfar.html|title=Transactions Tied to Weinstein and AIDS Charity Are Under Investigation|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}} ==== Harvey Weinstein Scandal ==== At amfAR's 22nd annual benefit in [[Cannes]], France in May 2015, [[Harvey Weinstein]] made a deal with amfAR chairman [[Kenneth Cole (designer)|Kenneth Cole]]. The deal is as follows: Weinstein would auction off two items (one being a sitting with a famous fashion photographer and the second being tickets to a Hollywood film awards event) on the condition that $600,000 of the proceeds raised at the auction would be donated as a charitable gift to the [[American Repertory Theater]]. The reason for this contingent was that the [[American Repertory Theater]] promised Weinstein a $1.25 million reimbursement and a $500,000 charitable donation to the play [[Finding Neverland (musical)|''Finding Neverland'']], which Weinstein was producing at the theater, on the condition that third parties donate the same amount to the production. While the arrangement raised $309,669 for amfAR and was ruled "legitimate and lawful" by the law firm Gibson, Dunn & Cutcher, investigations and public outrage ensued surrounding the charity's financial integrity. A rift formed between Chairman [[Kenneth Cole (designer)|Kenneth Cole]] and CEO Kevin Robert Frost, as evidenced by an email from Frost in 2015 saying, “Nothing about this deal feels right to me, and I believe we have not done due diligence to understand exactly what this money is being directed to or why amfAR is being used to facilitate these transfers."{{cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/12/harvey-weinstein-nightmare-finding-neverland-amfar-money|title='Nothing About This Deal Feels Right to Me': Inside Harvey Weinstein's Other Nightmare|last=Cohan|first=William D.|date=December 20, 2017|newspaper=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|accessdate=February 4, 2018}} AmfAR's management initially refused, citing their longstanding policy against doing so, but Weinstein was persistent. He had apparently donated $2 million to ART on the condition that if he could raise more money from others before June 1, 2015, they would return the contribution. Cole and Weinstein reportedly agreed that ART and AmfAR would split any money from the lots up to $1.2 million evenly, and all money above that amount would be exclusively AmfAR's. Except for a last-second insert attributed to Cole noting that ART would get some of the money from one of the lots, a fashion shoot with [[Mario Testino]], there was nothing else to indicate to bidders where their money was going. Cole told ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' later that he had always felt bullied by Weinstein, and the insert was a small act of resistance. Weinstein demanded AmFAR repay him immediately instead of waiting for the money for the lots to come in. In early 2016 the organization's board retained an attorney to investigate the transaction, who concluded that Weinstein's failure to disclose all relevant information had exposed AmfAR to material risks to its reputation if the deal had turned out to be illegal. The report divided the board, with several members resigning over what they saw as Cole's failures. After Weinstein found out that some of the people the lawyer talked to had shared information about [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations|his rumored history of sexual misconduct]], information that became public knowledge in September 2017, Weinstein demanded that board members who had read the report sign [[non-disclosure agreement]]s, leading to more resignations. In April 2017, 19 members of the Board of Trustees contacted the Attorney General to explain that Cole had proceeded with this deal in spite of the objections of the wider executive management team, as confirmed by their spokesperson Steven Goldberg. Following legal struggles surrounding the benefit to private investors of charitable donations, Weinstein pushed amfAR to sign nondisclosure agreements that indicated no wrongdoing and no further probing. As a result, four members (Mervyn Silverman, Vincent Roberti, Arlen Andelson and Jonathan Canno) refused to sign and went to petition the Attorney General on the impropriety of [[Kenneth Cole (designer)|Kenneth Cole]]. In that time two other board members had resigned. ==== Cole's Tenuous Term Limit Proposal ==== On November 13, NBC News obtained a letter signed by 60 gay rights community members calling for his resignation. This letter was signed by [[Greg Louganis]], an Olympic diver; [[Larry Kramer]], playwright and activist and amfAR contributor [[Peter Staley]], among others. As a result of the scandal, Kenneth Cole stepped down as chairman after a 14-year tenure.{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2018/02/08/kenneth-cole-resigns-amfar-chairman-following-harvey-weinstein-controversy/319180002/|title=Kenneth Cole resigns as amfAR chairman following Harvey Weinstein controversy|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}} Cole initially couched his decision to step down, along with four other board members,{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/harvey-weinstein-kenneth-cole_us_59e4bfa1e4b03a7be58224de|title=How Harvey Weinstein And Kenneth Cole Covered Up A Shady Deal|last=Ali|first=Yashar|date=2017-10-18|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-US}} as the result of term limits being imposed by the amfAR Board of Trustees with his support.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/sexual-misconduct/kenneth-cole-resigns-amfar-chair-wake-weinstein-flap-n845951|title=Kenneth Cole pushed out as amfAR chair in wake of Weinstein flap|work=NBC News|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-US}} Later, however, the attorney general's charity bureau sent a letter to the board on 2 February, which exposed a proposal by Cole which allowed him to maintain his role as chairman in spite of new term limits. The attorney general's office sent a second letter on 6 February that mandated the board update its term limits and end Cole's tenure. The attorney general allowed him to stay as a non-voting member for six months while his replacement is determined. With the calls for resignation by many on the Board of Trustees, and a mandate from New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman's office, Cole announced his decision to step down at an amfAR gala on Wednesday, February 7, 2018.{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/entertainment/kenneth-cole-steps-amfar-chairman-controversy-article-1.3808278|title=Kenneth Cole steps down as amfAR chairman amid controversy - NY Daily News|last=Press|first=The Associated|work=nydailynews.com|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-US}} == See Also == * [[Timeline of HIV/AIDS]] * [[Luc Montagnier|Luc Montagnier - Recipient of Mathilde Krim Fellowship for Basic Biomedical Research]] * [[ACT UP]] * [[Denver principles|Denver Principles]] * [[People With AIDS]] * [[Management of HIV/AIDS]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.amfar.org/ Official website] [[Category:AIDS activism]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS research institutes]] [[Category:International medical and health organizations]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in New York City]]

Arden Pope, speaking at [[Utah Valley University]], September 18, 2008. | residence = [[Springville, Utah]] | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = Professor | years_active = | known_for = Studies on the health effects of air pollution | notable_works = ''Respiratory hospital admissions associated with PM10 pollution in Utah, Salt Lake, and Cache Valleys. (1991)'' | title = Mary Lou Fulton Professor of Economics | alma_mater = [[Iowa State University]] (PhD, MS)
[[Brigham Young University]] (BS) | employer = Brigham Young University }} '''C. Arden Pope III''' (born c. 1954) is an [[United States|American]] professor of [[economics]] at [[Brigham Young University]] and one of the world's foremost experts{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/11/131108-lung-cancer-childhood-china-pollution-eight-year-old-girl/|title=A Chinese Child’s Lung Cancer Is Linked to Pollution|publisher=National Geographic|date=10 November 2013|last=Brink|first=Susan|quote=We talked with C. Arden Pope, economics professor at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah. His research into the effects of air pollution on human health and mortality has been instrumental in establishing federal air quality regulations. }}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/31/opinion/sunday/holding-your-breath-in-india.html?_r=0|title=Holding Your Breath in India|publisher=New York Times|date=29 May 2015|last=Harris|first=Gardiner|quote=C. Arden Pope III, a professor of economics at Brigham Young University and a leading expert on the health consequences of air pollution...}}{{cite web|url=http://www.timeoutbeijing.com/features/Sports__Fitness-Mind__Body/15375/Is-Beijing-air-as-bad-as-you-think.html|title=Is Beijing air as bad as you think?|publisher=Time Out Beijing|date=7 May 2014|quote=...Dr C Arden Pope III, one of the world’s top environmental science experts...}} in [[environmental science]]. He received his B.S. from Brigham Young University (BYU) in 1978 and his Ph.D. in Economics and [[statistics]] from [[Iowa State University]] in 1981. Although his research includes many papers on topics in the fields in which he was trained—[[environmental economics]], [[resource economics]], and [[agricultural economics]]—he is better known for his cross-disciplinary work in [[environmental epidemiology]] and [[public health]]. He is world-renowned for his seminal work on the effects of [[particulate]] [[air pollution]] on [[wikt:mortality|mortality]] and [[health]]. His articles have helped establish the connection between air pollution and health problems, including [[cancer]], [[cardiovascular]], and [[pulmonary disease]]. These research findings have influenced [[environmental policy]] in the United States and [[Europe]], contributing to the establishment of [[emission standard]]s for [[Atmospheric particulate matter|particulate matter]] pollution. ==Air pollution research== Early in Pope's career he published a paper that made him an academic cornerstone of environmental science and policy called "Respiratory hospital admissions associated with PM10 pollution in Utah, Salt Lake, and Cache Valleys".{{cite journal | doi=10.1080/00039896.1991.9937434 | last=Pope | first=C. A. | title=Respiratory hospital admissions associated with PM10 pollution in Utah, Salt Lake, and Cache Valleys | journal=Arch. Environ. Health | year=1991 | volume=46 | issue=2 | pages=90–97 | pmid=2006899 }} In [[Utah Valley]] the [[Geneva Steel]] Mill generated large quantities of particulate matter which is a byproduct of [[fossil fuel]] consumption. The mill was shut down temporarily. Pope compiled hospital admissions data for the time before, during, and after the temporary closing of the mill and was the first to convincingly show the immediate health harms associated with [[atmospheric particulate matter]].{{fact|date=August 2018}} [[Asthma]], [[wikt:mortality|mortality]], and [[respiratory]] admissions generally were twice as high while the plant was operating than the year in which it was closed. [[Utah]] made a particularly suitable [[natural experiment]] as the various valleys included in the study trap pollution in the winter months when [[Inversion (meteorology)|temperature inversions]] stifle the escape of pollution. His abstract states: {{cquote|This study assessed the association between respiratory hospital admissions and PM10 pollution in Utah, Salt Lake, and Cache valleys during April 1985 through March 1989. Utah and Salt Lake valleys had high levels of PM10 pollution that violated both the annual and 24-h standards issued by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Much lower PM10 levels occurred in the Cache Valley. Utah Valley experienced the intermittent operation of its primary source of PM10 pollution: an integrated steel mill. Bronchitis and asthma admissions for preschool-age children were approximately twice as frequent in Utah Valley when the steel mill was operating versus when it was not. Similar differences were not observed in Salt Lake or Cache valleys. Even though Cache Valley had higher smoking rates and lower temperatures in winter than did Utah Valley, per capita bronchitis and asthma admissions for all ages were approximately twice as high in Utah Valley. During the period when the steel mill was closed, differences in per capita admissions between Utah and Cache valleys narrowed considerably. Regression analysis also demonstrated a statistical association between respiratory hospital admissions and PM10 pollution. The results suggest that PM10 pollution plays a role in the incidence and severity of respiratory disease.|20px||C. Arden Pope}} Pope came under hostile political pressure and his findings became a firestorm of controversy. Intense scrutiny revealed that his results were accurate. In 2004 Pope was awarded the [[Utah Governor's Medal in Science and Technology]]. In 2006 Dr. Pope was recognized as BYU's distinguished faculty through reception of the [[Karl G. Maeser]] award.https://news.byu.edu/news/byu-honors-outstanding-faculty-staff-annual-university-conference ==References== * {{cite journal | last=Smart | first=Michael D. | title=Clearing the Air | journal=BYU Magazine | date=Spring 2007 | url=http://magazine.byu.edu/?act=view&a=1990 | accessdate=2007-05-22 }} {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite journal | last=Dockery | first=Douglas W. |author2=C. Arden Pope |author3=Xiping Xu |author4=John D. Spengler |author5=James H. Ware |author6=Martha E. Fay |author7=Benjamin G. Ferris |author8=Frank E. Speizer | title=An Association between Air Pollution and Mortality in Six U.S. Cities | journal=[[New England Journal of Medicine|The New England Journal of Medicine]] | volume=329 | issue=24 | pages=1753–1759 | date=December 9, 1993 | url=https://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/abstract/329/24/1753 | pmid=8179653 | accessdate=2008-02-21 | doi=10.1056/NEJM199312093292401}} * {{cite journal | last=Pope | first=C. Arden, III |author2=Richard T. Burnett |author3=Michael J. Thun |author4=Eugenia E. Calle |author5=Daniel Krewski |author6=Kazuhiko Ito |author7=George D. Thurston | title=Lung Cancer, Cardiopulmonary Mortality, and Long-term Exposure to Fine Particulate Air Pollution | journal=[[Journal of the American Medical Association]] | volume=287 | issue=9 | pages=1132–1141 | date=March 6, 2002 | url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/287/9/1132 | accessdate=2008-02-21 | doi=10.1001/jama.287.9.1132 |pmid=11879110 |pmc=4037163}} * {{cite journal | last=Dockery | first=D. W. |author2=C. A. Pope | title=Acute Respiratory Effects of Particulate Air Pollution | journal=[[Annual Review of Public Health]] | volume=15 | pages=107–132 | date=May 1994 | url=http://arjournals.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.pu.15.050194.000543 | accessdate=2008-02-21 | doi=10.1146/annurev.pu.15.050194.000543 | pmid=8054077}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130708183346/https://economics.byu.edu/Pages/Faculty/C-Arden-Pope.aspx Faculty page @ BYU] * [https://economics.byu.edu/SiteAssets/Pages/Faculty/C-Arden-Pope/A_Pope_VITA_2013_without%20pres.pdf CV]{{deadlink|date=August 2018}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110520041609/http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=3665914907157343039 Video of 2007 presentation to a local environmental group, Sevier Citizens for Clean Air and Water, in Richfield, Utah] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110716101121/http://www.noaca.org/pmhealtheffects.pdf Evidence Review of Particulate Matter Effects] * [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2006899 Utah Valley Paper that Shut Down Geneva Steel] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pope, C. '''Cannabis in Cambodia''' is illegal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Law on Drug Management (Drug Control)|url=http://www.cambodiainvestment.gov.kh/law-on-drug-management-drug-control_961209.html|website=Council for the Development of Cambodia|accessdate=16 July 2017|quote=Article 2: Except for the cases of the article 14, the cultivation of opium poppy, cocoa plants, cannabis indica and cannabis sativa in the Kingdom of Cambodia, shall be prohibited.}}</ref> This prohibition is enforced opportunistically.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Soenthrith|first1=Saing|title=Foreigners Arrested in Siem Reap Marijuana Bust|url=https://www.cambodiadaily.com/archives/foreigners-arrested-in-siem-reap-marijuana-bust-14816/|accessdate=16 July 2017|publisher=Phnom Penh Post|date=15 March 2013|language=English|quote=Police in Siem Reap City on Tuesday arrested 18 people, including 14 foreign nationals, during raids on two establishments, where they confiscated a stash of marijuana and an as-yet-unidentified powder, police said.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Goldberg|first1=Lina|title=Recreational drugs in Cambodia|url=http://www.movetocambodia.com/living-in-cambodia/safety-and-security/recreational-drugs-in-cambodia/|website=Move To Cambodia|accessdate=16 July 2017|quote=Foreigners are rarely prosecuted for small amounts of marijuana, but expect to pay a few bribes if you do get caught.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Harfenist|first1=Ethan|title=The high life|url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/post-weekend/high-life|accessdate=16 July 2017|agency=Phnom Penh Post|date=30 May 2015}}</ref> Many "Happy" restaurants located in [[Phnom Penh]], [[Siem Reap]] and [[Sihanoukville (city)|Sihanoukville]] publicly offer food cooked with [[marijuana]], or as a side garnish.<ref>{{citation |url = http://www.gosihanoukville.com/dining/happy/index.html |title = Happy Restaurants (sic) in Sihanoukville |publisher = GoSihanoukville.com |date = |accessdate = 2011-02-17 }}</ref>
==Law== ===History=== Cannabis was probably introduced to [[Southeast Asia]] around the 16th century, and used medicinally and in cuisine.<ref name="Cohen2012">{{cite book|author=Sidney Cohen|title=The Therapeutic Potential of Marihuana|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=89vTBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA3|date=6 December 2012|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1-4613-4286-1|pages=3–}}</ref> Cannabis has been traditionally grown in [[Cambodia]] and is a common ingredient in food. By 1961 in compliance with the Single Convention on Narcotics treaty it was technically made illegal but the law was unenforced, and marijuana was openly sold. In 1992 during a [[United Nations]] intervention the drug was specifically made illegal but still the law remained unenforced.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/post-weekend/high-life |title=The high life |website=phnompenhpost.com }}</ref>
===Enforcement=== Although it is illegal, police do not harass cannabis users and businesses openly sell cannabis products to the public.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marijuanatravels.com/cities/khm |title=Cambodia, Country |website=marijuanatravels.com }}</ref> As of 2009, the [[UNODC]] stated that cannabis production cultivation had "ceased to be a major concern" in Cambodia.<ref name="Brownfield2011">{{cite book|author=William R. Brownfield|title=International Narcotics Control Strategy Report: Volume I: Drug and Chemical Control|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0jnyNWFuhXYC&pg=PA179|date=May 2011|publisher=DIANE Publishing|isbn=978-1-4379-8272-5|pages=179–}}</ref>
==Culture== Marijuana is openly sold in markets, restaurants, and bars. "Happy pizza" is the term for cannabis infused pizza frequently sold in restaurants across Cambodia. Among Cambodians it is viewed as something older people use and is not popular with the youth.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cannabisculture.com/content/1998/11/01/1403 |title=Cannabis Cambodia: smoker’s paradise |website=cannabisculture.com }}</ref> In tourist heavy areas "happy pizza" is more commonly sold due to its popularity among travelers.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://theculturetrip.com/asia/cambodia/articles/visitors-are-so-happy-to-try-marijuana-laced-pizza-in-cambodia/ |title=Visitors are so happy to try marijuana-laced pizza in Cambodia |website=theculturetrip.com }}</ref>

revision.text:
The '''Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment for Alcohol''', commonly abbreviated as '''CIWA''' or '''CIWA-Ar''' (revised version), is a ten item scale used in the assessment and management of [[alcohol withdrawal]].<ref name="pmid2597811">{{cite journal|last1=Sullivan|first1=JT|last2=Sykora|first2=K|last3=Schneiderman|first3=J|last4=Naranjo|first4=CA|last5=Sellers|first5=EM|title=Assessment of alcohol withdrawal: the revised clinical institute withdrawal assessment for alcohol scale (CIWA-Ar).|journal=British Journal of Addiction|date=November 1989|volume=84|issue=11|pages=1353–7|doi=10.1111/j.1360-0443.1989.tb00737.x|pmid=2597811}}</ref><ref name="pmid8046805">{{cite journal|last1=Saitz|first1=R|last2=Mayo-Smith|first2=MF|last3=Roberts|first3=MS|last4=Redmond|first4=HA|last5=Bernard|first5=DR|last6=Calkins|first6=DR|title=Individualized treatment for alcohol withdrawal. A randomized double-blind controlled trial.|journal=JAMA|date=17 August 1994|volume=272|issue=7|pages=519–23|pmid=8046805|doi=10.1001/jama.272.7.519}}</ref> Each item on the scale is scored independently, and the summation of the scores yields an aggregate value that correlates to the severity of alcohol withdrawal, with ranges of scores designed to prompt specific management decisions such as the administration of [[benzodiazepines]]. The maximum score is 67; Mild alcohol withdrawal is defined with a score less than or equal to 15, moderate with scores of 16 to 20, and severe with any score greater than 20. The ten items evaluated on the scale are common symptoms and signs of alcohol withdrawal, and are as follows: *[[Nausea]] and vomiting *Tremor *[[Paroxysmal]] sweats *Anxiety *Agitation *[[Touch|Tactile]] disturbances *[[Hearing (sense)|Auditory]] disturbances *[[Visual disturbances]] *[[Headache]] *Orientation and clouded [[sensorium]] All items are scored from 0–7, with the exception of the orientation category, scored from 0–4. The CIWA scale is validated and has high inter-rater reliability. A randomized, [[double blind]] trial published in ''[[JAMA (journal)|JAMA]]'' in 1994<ref>Saitz M, Mayo-Smith MF, Redmond HA, Bernard DR, Calkins DR. Individualized treatment for alcohol withdrawal. A randomized double-blind controlled trial. JAMA 1994;272:519-23.</ref> showed that management for alcohol withdrawal that was guided by the CIWA scale resulted in decreased treatment duration and total use of [[benzodiazepines]]. The goal of the CIWA scale is to provide an efficient and objective means of assessing alcohol withdrawal. Studies have shown that use of the scale in management of alcohol withdrawal leads to decreased frequency of over-sedation with benzodiazepines in patients with milder alcohol withdrawal than would otherwise be detected without use of the scale, and decreased frequency of under-treatment in patients with greater severity of withdrawal than would otherwise be determined without the scale.<ref name="pmid9214531">{{cite journal|last1=Mayo-Smith|first1=MF|title=Pharmacological management of alcohol withdrawal. A meta-analysis and evidence-based practice guideline. American Society of Addiction Medicine Working Group on Pharmacological Management of Alcohol Withdrawal.|journal=JAMA|date=9 July 1997|volume=278|issue=2|pages=144–51|pmid=9214531|doi=10.1001/jama.278.2.144}}</ref>
The CIWA-Ar is actually a shortened, yet improved version of the CIWA, geared towards objectifying alcohol withdrawal symptom severity. It retains validity, usefulness and reliability between raters.<ref name="pmid9214531" />
==See also== * [[Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test|AUDIT]]<ref name="pmid12296504">{{cite journal|last1=Reoux|first1=Joseph P.|last2=Malte|first2=Carol A.|last3=Kivlahan|first3=Daniel R.|last4=Saxon|first4=Andrew J.|title=The Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT) Predicts Alcohol Withdrawal Symptoms During Inpatient Detoxification|journal=Journal of Addictive Diseases|date=20 September 2002|volume=21|issue=4|pages=81–91|doi=10.1300/J069v21n04_08|pmid=12296504}}</ref><ref name="pmid24197633">{{cite journal|last1=Williams|first1=Kendal|last2=Mitchell|first2=Matthew|title=Inpatient Alcohol Withdrawal: Time to Prevent the Preventable?|journal=Journal of General Internal Medicine|date=6 November 2013|volume=29|issue=1|pages=7–9|doi=10.1007/s11606-013-2642-7|pmid=24197633|pmc=3889962}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.reseaufranco.com/en/assessment_and_treatment_information/assessment_tools/clinical_institute_withdrawal_assessment_for_alcohol_ciwa.pdf CIWA Score for Alcohol Withdrawal] format *[http://www.mdcalc.com/ciwa-ar-for-alcohol-withdrawal/ CIWA Score for Alcohol Withdrawal] online calculator *[https://books.google.com/books?id=54yUzyDiTJ0C&pg=PA46&lpg=PA46&dq=original+ciwa+scale&source=bl&ots=pGpPOE6wIC&sig=o94VbwA5OUK_AQRCwhhwrLtKyJQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ibU2VYLbE8GhyATd3IDQCQ&ved=0CHoQ6AEwEg#v=onepage&q=original%20ciwa%20scale&f=false The Essential Handbook of Treatment and Prevention of Alcohol Problems]
