The 2010 maternal mortality rate per 100,000 births for Tanzania was 790. This is compared with 449 in 2008 and 610.2 in 1990. The UN Child Mortality Report 2011 reports a decrease in under-five mortality from 155 per 1,000 live births in 1990 to 76 per 1,000 live births in 2010, and in neonatal mortality from 40 per 1,000 live births to 26 per 1,000 live births.<ref name="Child Mortality Report 2011">{{cite web|title=UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation|url=http://www.unicef.org/media/files/Child_Mortality_Report_2011_Final.pdf|date=22 September 2011}}</ref> The aim of the report The State of the World's Midwifery is to highlight ways in which the [[Millennium Development Goals]] can be achieved, particularly Goal 4 – Reduce child mortality and Goal 5 – improve maternal health. In Tanzania there are only two midwives per 1,000 live births; and the lifetime risk of death during delivery for women is one in 23.<ref name="SOWMY">{{cite web|url=http://www.unfpa.org/sowmy/report/home.html|title=The State Of The World's Midwifery|publisher=United Nations Population Fund|access-date=1 August 2011}}</ref>
===Maternal and child health status=== Both maternal and child health are interdependent and substantially contributing to high burden of [[Death|mortality]] worldwide. Every year, 289,000 women die due to complications in pregnancy and childbirth, and 6.6 million children below 5 years of age die of complications in the newborn period and of common childhood diseases.<ref>{{cite web|author=WHO|title=Consultation on improving measurement of the quality of maternal, newborn and child care in health facilities|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/128206/1/9789241507417_eng.pdf?ua=1|accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] (SSA), which includes [[Tanzania]], contribute higher proportion of maternal and child mortality. Due to considerable proportion of mortality being attributed by maternal and child health, the [[United Nations]] together with other international agencies incorporated the two into [[Millennium Development Goals]] (MDGs) 4 and 5. In this regard, Tanzania through the [[Ministry of Health and Social Welfare (Tanzania)|Ministry of Health and Social Welfare]] (MoHSW) adopted different strategies and efforts to promote safe motherhood and improve [[child survival]]. Similarly, in an effort to improve maternal and child health, Tanzania’s government has declared maternal and child health services to be exempt from user fees in government facilities.
===Maternal health indicators===
====Maternal mortality ratio====
Complications during pregnancy and childbirth are a leading cause of death and disability among women of reproductive age in developing countries. Statistically, maternal mortality contributes to only 2.3 per cent of the total mortality.<ref name="UNDP">{{cite web | author=UNDP | title=Tanzania MDG 5: Improve maternal health | url=http://www.tz.undp.org/content/tanzania/en/home/mdgoverview/overview/mdg5 | accessdate=2 September 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140907074303/http://www.tz.undp.org/content/tanzania/en/home/mdgoverview/overview/mdg5/ | archivedate=7 September 2014 | df= }}</ref> The maternal mortality ratio (MMR) represents the risk associated with each pregnancy.<ref name="WHOMM">{{cite web | author=World Health Organization | title=Health statistics and information systems-MMR | url=http://www.who.int/healthinfo/statistics/indmaternalmortality/en | accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> MMR is estimated by using both number of [[maternal deaths]] and live births. Many low-income countries have no or very little data and modelling is used to obtain a national estimate.<ref name="WHOMM"/> According to estimates in 2013, total maternal deaths and MMR in Tanzania were 7,900 and 410 per 100,000 live births respectively.<ref name="COUNTDOWN">{{cite web | title=Countdown 2014 report for Tanzania | url=http://www.countdown2015mnch.org/documents/2014Report/TanzaniaURep_Country_Profile_2014.pdf | accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> In relation to MDG 5, Tanzania is supposed to reach the MMR of 230 per 100,000 live births by 2015. Reduction of maternal deaths is one of the main goals of the Tanzanian poverty reduction strategy<ref>[http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/scr/2011/cr1117.pdf ''National Strategy for Growth and Reduction of Poverty II'', Tanzania Ministry of Finance and Economic Affairs, July 2010, page 73, accessed 26 October 2014]</ref> and the health sector reform program, but progress has been slow. The slow progress in reducing maternal mortality on mainland Tanzania is compounded by the impact of the [[HIV/AIDS]] epidemic.<ref name="UNDP"/>
====Antenatal care coverage====
Good care during pregnancy is important for the health of the mother and the development of the unborn baby.<ref>{{cite web | author=WHO | title=Antenatal care -chapter 2 | url=http://www.who.int/pmnch/media/publications/aonsectionIII_2.pdf | accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> Many health problems in pregnant women can be prevented, detected, and treated during antenatal care visits with trained health workers.<ref>{{cite web | author=WHO | title=Global Health Observatory (ANC) | url=http://www.who.int/gho/maternal_health/reproductive_health/antenatal_care_text/en | accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> The [[World Health Organization]] recommends a minimum of four antenatal care (ANC) visits. The ''Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey 2010'' showed that 98 percent made at least one ANC visit and 43 percent made four or more visits.<ref>[http://www.nbs.go.tz/nbs/takwimu/references/2010TDHS.pdf Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey 2010, National Bureau of Statistics, Tanzania Ministry of Health and Social Welfare, April 2011, page 129, accessed 26 October 2014]</ref>
====Skilled birth deliveries==== This indicator is directly linked to a process of giving birth by pregnant woman, and most of maternal [[Death|mortality]] are likely to happen at this stage. Most maternal deaths result from haemorrhage, complications of unsafe [[abortion]], pregnancy-induced [[hypertension]], [[sepsis]] and [[obstructed labour]].<ref name="UNFPA">{{cite web|author=UNFPA|title=REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH IN REFUGEE SITUATIONS: AN INTER-AGENCY FIELD MANUAL|url=https://www.unfpa.org/emergencies/manual/3.htm|accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> However, these proportions of causes for maternal deaths are likely to differ from one country to another. According to official estimates, more than 20 women die of pregnancy and childbirth-related complications every day in [[Tanzania]].<ref>{{cite web|author=White Ribbon Alliance|title=TANZANIA JOINS GLOBAL EFFORTS TO SAVE MOTHERS, NEWBORN LIVES|url=http://whiteribbonalliance.org/wra-page-release/tanzania-joins-global-efforts-save-mothers-newborn-lives/|accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> Ensuring that mothers have access to a skilled attendant during labour can dramatically reduce the risk of death for the mother and newborn child.<ref>{{cite web|author=WAHA|title=Health topic: Maternal health|url=http://www.waha-international.org/?health-topics|accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> In the 2010 [[Tanzania]] DHS, about 51% of deliveries were assisted by skilled personnel. While it was 41% in 1999 Tanzania DHS. Potentially the current figure national-wide will be more than 51 per cent. Shortage of health providers, among others, are limiting factors to be delivered by skilled provider. The ratio of doctors to patients in Tanzania is 1:25,000 and the ratio of nurses to patients is 1:23,000. While the ratio in the [[United States]] is 1:300.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jakaya Kikwete|title=THE FIGHT FOR MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH IN SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA|url=http://www.ghdnews.com/index.php/global-health-challenges/maternal-and-child-health/45-the-fight-for-maternal-and-child-health-in-sub-saharan-africa|publisher=GHD WINTER 2014 DIGITAL EDITION|accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> [[President]] [[Jakaya Kikwete]] on May 2014 appealed to health workers in Tanzania to ensure that lives of women and children are not at risk during delivery.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lucas Lukumbo|title=PRESIDENT KIKWETE TO HEALTH WORKERS: YOU CAN STOP MATERNAL AND CHILD DEATHS|url=http://whiteribbonalliance.org/media/president-kikwete-health-workers-can-stop-maternal-child-deaths/|publisher=IPP MEDIA, White Ribbon Alliance|accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> In Tanzania, two thirds of women give birth in their own homes, because there are very few health facilities within reach that can provide life-saving emergency services.<ref>{{cite web|author=White Ribbon Alliance|title=CAMPAIGN UPDATE: TANZANIA ONE STEP CLOSER TO LIFE SAVING CARE FOR WOMEN|url=http://whiteribbonalliance.org/opinions/campaign-update-tanzania-one-step-closer-life-saving-care-women/|accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref>
====Postnatal care coverage==== Every year in [[Africa]], at least 125,000 women and 870,000 newborns die in the first week after birth, yet this is when coverage and programmes are at their lowest along the continuum of care.<ref name="WHOPMNCH">{{cite web|author=WHO|title=Postnatal care -chapter 4|url=http://www.who.int/pmnch/media/publications/aonsectionIII_4.pdf|accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> Since up to 50 per cent of maternal deaths occurs after delivery, a midwife or a trained and supervised Traditional Birth Attendant (TBA) should visit all mothers as soon as possible within the first 24–48 hours after birth.<ref name="UNFPA"/> The 2010 figure in utilizing postnatal care in Tanzania was only 31 per cent according to TDHS.<ref name="TDHS">{{cite web|author=USAID|publisher=TANZANIA DHS|date=2010|title=Demographic and Health Survey|url=http://dhsprogram.com/pubs/pdf/FR243/FR243%5B24June2011%5D.pdf|accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> Coverage of postnatal check-up within 4 hours after birth varies from 9 percent in the Lake zone to 34 percent in the Southern zone in Tanzania.<ref name="TDHS"/> Postnatal care (PNC) programmes are among the weakest of all reproductive and child health programmes in [[Tanzania]] and [[Sub-Saharan African]] in general.<ref name="WHOPMNCH"/> Given the absence of PNC guidelines in Tanzania, the Reproductive and Child Health Section (RCHS) of the [[Ministry of Health and Social Welfare (Tanzania)|Ministry of Health and Social Welfare]] [Tanzania] reported in 2009 that is in the process of developing it to be used country-wide.<ref name="MRISHO">{{cite web|author=Mrisho|date=2009|title= The use of antenatal and postnatal care: perspectives and experiences of women and health care providers in rural southern Tanzania|url=http://www.biomedcentral.com/content/pdf/1471-2393-9-10.pdf|publisher=BMC Pregnancy and Childbirth|accessdate=2 September 2014|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
====Modern family planning use==== The policy environment for [[family planning]] in Tanzania is mixed, but promising. At the 2012 London Summit on Family Planning, President [[Kikwete]] highlighted Tanzania's continued efforts to improve family planning. He mentioned the [[National Strategy for Growth and Reduction of Poverty]] (MKUKUTA II) which has a strong family planning component, and the National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan (2010) which endeavors to reach a contraceptive prevalence target of 60% of all women by 2015 and will require $88.2 million between 2010 and 2015.<ref>{{cite web|author=WHO|url=http://advancefamilyplanning.org/tanzania|title=Tanzania|access-date=2 September 2014}}</ref> Like many countries in sub-Saharan Africa, Tanzania's once successful family planning program has slowed markedly, with rates of contraceptive prevalence well below levels needed to reach current demand and country goals.<ref>{{cite web|author=FHI360|title=PROGRESS in Tanzania: National Family Planning Costed Implementation Program|url=http://www.fhi360.org/projects/progress-tanzania-national-family-planning-costed-implementation-program|accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> In Tanzania, 34.4 percent of married women in 2010 reported use of any method of contraception, while modern methods reached a prevalence of 27.4 per cent.<ref name="TDHS"/> Factors limiting contraceptive prevalence in Tanzania include widespread misconceptions and concerns about side-effects, low acceptance of long–acting methods, erratic supplies and a limited range of choices, gaps in provider knowledge and skills (along with provider bias), competing priorities pursuing scarce resources, limited male involvement, poor communication between spouses, and the perceived value of large families also contribute to low use of family planning methods.<ref>{{cite web|author=PATHFINDER|title=Reproductive Health and Family Planning in Tanzania: The Pathfinder International Experience|url=http://www.pathfinder.org/publications-tools/pdfs/Reproductive-Health-and-Family-Planning-in-Tanzania-The-Pathfinder-International-Experience.pdf|accessdate=2 September 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723213857/http://www.pathfinder.org/publications-tools/pdfs/Reproductive-Health-and-Family-Planning-in-Tanzania-The-Pathfinder-International-Experience.pdf|archivedate=23 July 2015|df=}}</ref>
===Child health indicators===
====Infant and under-five mortality rate====
Children in sub-Saharan Africa are about over 16 times more likely to die before the age of five than children in developed regions.<ref>{{cite web | author=WHO | title=Fact sheet- reducing child mortality | url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs178/en | accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> Tanzania has reduced the [[infant mortality]] rate (IMR) of 101 to 38 per 1000 live births from 1990 to 2012 respectively.<ref name="COUNTDOWN"/><ref name="TDHS"/><ref>{{cite web | author=WHO | title=Global Health Observatory Data Repository-Infant mortality | url=http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.526?lang=en|accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> Also, it has reduced substantially the under-five mortality rate (U5MR) of 166 to 54 per 1000 live births from 1990 to 2012 respectively.<ref name="COUNTDOWN"/><ref name="TDHS"/><ref>{{cite web | author=WHO | title=Global Health Observatory Data Repository-Under 5 mortality | url=http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.525?lang=en | accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref>
[[Malaria]] is the leading cause of death for Tanzanian children and is a major cause of maternal mortality.<ref>{{cite web | author=GHI | title=Tanzania Global Health Initiative Strategy 2010 -2015 | url=http://www.ghi.gov/whereWeWork/docs/TanzaniaStrategy.pdf | accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> Tanzania is making considerable progress in the reduction of child mortality.<ref>{{cite web | author=UNICEF | title=Tanzania’s progress in maternal and child health | url=http://www.unicef.org/tanzania/6906_10741.html | accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> In that respect, Tanzania is likely to achieve MDG 4 of reducing child mortality.<ref name="UNDPMDG4">{{cite web | author=UNDP | title=Tanzania MDG4: Reduce child mortality | url=http://www.tz.undp.org/content/tanzania/en/home/mdgoverview/overview/mdg4 | accessdate=3 September 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140907052451/http://www.tz.undp.org/content/tanzania/en/home/mdgoverview/overview/mdg4/ | archivedate=7 September 2014 | df= }}</ref> The most significant contribution to the reduction of under-five mortality is improved control measures of malaria, Acute Respiratory Infections, diarrhea; improved personal hygiene, environmental sanitation; and preventive, promotive as well as curative health services.<ref name="UNDPMDG4"/> Tanzania's average annual rate of reduction of child mortality over the last 15 years was 4.6%, while, the Millennium Development Goal rate set by UN is an annual average rate of reduction of 4.3 percent.<ref name="GAPMINDER">{{cite web | author=GAPMINDER | title=Tanzania: Fast drop in child mortality! | url=http://www.gapminder.org/news/tanzania-fast-drop-in-child-mortality/#.VAdgRfmSzRs | accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref>
====Vaccination coverage==== There have been improvements in the planning process, community ownership and involvement, improving coverage, effective mobilization of funds for the Expanded Program of Immunisation, improvements in the safety of vaccine delivery and introduction of new and underutilized vaccines.<ref>{{cite web|author=WHO|title=Tanzania:Immunization and vaccines development (IVD)|url=http://www.afro.who.int/en/tanzania/country-programmes/3112-immunization-and-vaccines-development-ivd.html|accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> According to 2010 Demographic and Health Survey in Tanzania, 66% at 12 months of age were fully immunised during the survey.<ref name="TDHS"/> The 2010 DHS in Tanzania which is the latest, presents the BCG coverage of 95.5%, [[DPT vaccine]] coverage of 88%; Polio (Pol3) coverage of 84.9% and Measles coverage of 84.5%. The proportion of children vaccinated against measles increased from 80% in 2005 to 85% in 2010.<ref name="UNDPMDG4"/> But the vaccination coverage in Tanzania presented to be more that 90% for each of the above vaccines according to [[World Health Organization]] in 2012.<ref name="WHOA824">{{cite web|author=WHO|title=Global Health Observatory Data Repository-Immunization|url=http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.A824?lang=en|accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! BCG !! DTP3!! Pol3 !! Measles |- | DHS 2010<ref name="TDHS"/> || 95.5% || 88.0% || 84.9% || 84.5% |- | WHO 2012<ref name="WHOA824"/> || 99.0% || 92.0% || 90.0% || 97.0% |}
The government of Tanzania via the Minister of Health and Social Welfare, has urged in 2012 partners and stakeholders in the country to join the National Immunization Coordination Committee to ensure that all children in Tanzanian are covered.<ref>{{cite web|author=IPP MEDIA|title=Minister: Children's immunization coverage satisfactory|url=http://www.ippmedia.com/frontend/?l=48917|accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref>
An Electronic Immunisation Register has been established, which permits online access to the medical records of mothers and infants, enabling vaccination teams in remote areas to operate more effectively, especially with nomadic people. It also helps to coordinate stock levels and order new supplies.<ref>{{cite news |title=Good data saves lives |url=http://gotlife.gavi.org/features/good-data-saves-lives/ |accessdate=28 November 2018 |publisher=Gavi |date=2018}}</ref>
====Exclusive breastfeeding==== In Tanzania by 2010, [[breastfeeding]] was initiated within the first hour of birth in 46.1% of mothers.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Victor |first1=R |last2=Baines |first2=SK |last3=Agho |first3=KE |last4=Dibley |first4=MJ |date=7 January 2013|title=Determinants of breastfeeding indicators among children less than 24 months of age in Tanzania: a secondary analysis of the 2010 Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey |url=http://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/3/1/e001529.full.pdf+html |journal=BMJ Open |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=e001529 |doi=10.1136/bmjopen-2012-001529|pmid=23299109 }} {{open access}}</ref> Over 97 percent of mothers in Tanzania do breastfeed, however, the prevalence of exclusive breastfeeding in infants aged 0–6 months is 50 percent.<ref name="TDHS"/><ref>{{cite web|author=WHO|title=Global Health Observatory Data Repository -Exclusive breastfeeding under 6 months|url=http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.1100?lang=en|accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> Although the national average reported to be 50% prevalence, one regional study focusing on Kilimanjaro region only revealed the general prevalence of 88.1% at one month, 65.5% at three months and 20.7% for an infant of six months of age, which is very low and did not vary between rural and urban.<ref name="MGONGO">{{cite web|author=Mgongo|date=2013|title=Prevalence and predictors of exclusive breastfeeding among women in Kilimanjaro region, Northern Tanzania: a population based cross-sectional study|url=http://www.internationalbreastfeedingjournal.com/content/pdf/1746-4358-8-12.pdf|publisher=International Breastfeeding Journal|accessdate=3 September 2014|display-authors=etal}}</ref> A [[multivariate analysis]] using 2010 TDHS data<ref name="MGONGO"/> revealed that the risk of delayed initiation of breastfeeding within 1 hour after birth was significantly higher among young mothers aged <24 years, uneducated and employed mothers from rural areas who delivered by caesarean section and those who delivered at home and were assisted by traditional birth attendants or relatives. The risk factors associated with non-exclusive breastfeeding, during the first 6 months, were lack of professional assistance at birth and residence in urban areas.
====Child malnutrition==== [[Malnutrition]] in Tanzania is a contributing factor in an estimated 130 child deaths every day.<ref name="UNICEF TANZANIA">{{cite web|author=UNICEF|title=Tanzania overview -nutrition|url=http://www.unicef.org/tanzania/10787_11047.html|accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> According to 2010 TDHS, about 42 percent of children are stunted, 16 percent are underweight and 5 percent are wasted.<ref name="TDHS"/> Different efforts have been adopted in Tanzania to improve children nutrition status. Within a one-year interval from 2010 and 2011, significant reduction in malnutrition observed. In 2011 according to [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) estimates on child malnutrition in Tanzania, children aged <5 years stunted was 34.8% in 2011; underweight was 13.6% in 2011; wasted was 6.6% in 2011 and overweight was 5.5% in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|author=WHO|title=Global Health Observatory Data Repository -Child malnutrition|url=http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.1095?lang=en|accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> Some regions in Tanzania like [[Iringa]], [[Mbeya]] and [[Rukwa]] are among the five regions with the highest stunting and are all areas with high food production.<ref name="UNICEF TANZANIA"/> The case in Tanzania, is inconsistent with the common assumption that increasing agriculture and food production will automatically lead to improvements in nutrition.
==== Neonatal and under-five mortality 2030 ==== Reducing the number of children dying before their fifth birthday has been targeted in the [[Sustainable Development Goals]] under the health related goals. [[Tanzania]] has made an improvement in attaining the reduction of child mortality;<ref name="Tanzania MDG report 2014">{{cite web|last1=UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA|title=Country Report on Millennium Development Goals 2014, Entering 2015 with better MDG Scores|url=http://www.undp.org/content/dam/undp/library/MDG/english/MDG%20Country%20Reports/MDGR%202014_TZ.pdf|website=UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA|accessdate=5 September 2015}}</ref> however, based on the Sustainable Development Goals, the country should further reduce in exact numbers the neonatal and under-five mortality rates by 2030.<ref name="United Nations:Sustainable Development Goals" />
=====Sustainable Development Goals===== [[Sustainable development goals]] have been developed as a new development agenda after the expiration of the [[Millennium Development Goals]] in 2015. The third sustainable development goal aims to enhance healthy lives and promote wellbeing for all at all ages.<ref name="United Nations:Sustainable Development Goals">{{cite web|last1=United Nations|title=Sustainable Development Goals|url=https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/sustainable-development-goals/|website=United Nations|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref>
=====SDG 3, target 3.2===== The health related [https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/sustainable-development-goals/ Sustainable Development Goal 3, target 3.2] targets a reduction of neonatal mortality to 12 per 1000 live births and under five mortality rate to 25 per 1000 live births by 2030.<ref name="United Nations:Sustainable Development Goals" /> The world under five mortality rate has declined from 90 in 1990 to 46 in 2013.<ref name="UNICEF:State of the World's Children 2015">{{cite web|last1=UNICEF|title=State of the World's Children 2015|url=http://sowc2015.unicef.org/|website=UNICEF|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref> In Tanzania, the U5MR has declined from 167 in 1990 to 52 in 2013.<ref>[http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.525]</ref> The country ranks the 48 in the world in 2013 in under five mortality out of 194 countries.<ref name="WHO:Under-five mortality data by country">{{cite web|last1=WHO|title=Under-five mortality data by country|url=http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.525|website=WHO: Global Health Observatory Data Repository|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> Figure 1 shows a comparison of under five mortality rate between the World and Tanzania with data from State of the World's Children 2015 Report<ref name="UNICEF:State of the World's Children 2015" /> and WHO,Global Health Observatory Data Repository.<ref name="WHO:Under-five mortality data by country" /> Figure 2 shows a comparison of Neonatal Mortality rates between the World and Tanzania with data from UNICEF 2013 Child Mortality Report.<ref name="UNICEF: Child Mortality report 2013">{{cite web|last1=UNICEF|title=Child Mortality Report 2013|url=http://www.unicef.org/media/files/2013_IGME_child_mortality_Report.pdf|website=UNICEF|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref>
[[File:World vs Tanzanian Under five mortality rate.png|thumb|A comparison of Under5 mortality between Tanzania and the world]] [[File:World vs Tanzania Neonatal Mortality rate.png|thumb|World vs Tanzania Neonatal Mortality rate]]
===HIV/AIDS=== Tanzania faces a "mature", generalized [[HIV]] epidemic. Among the 1.4 million people living with [[HIV]]/AIDS, 70.5 percent are 25 to 49 years old, and 15 percent are 15–24 years. In young women ages 15 to 24, there is an HIV prevalence rate of 3.8 percent, which is significantly higher than the 2.8 percent prevalence rate among young men in the same [[Demographic profile|age group]]. More than half of available hospital beds are occupied by HIV-infected persons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/countryfocus/cooperation_strategy/ccs_tza_en.pdf|title=WHO country cooperation strategy 2002-2005}}</ref> HIV is the leading cause of mortality in Tanzania, accounting for 17% of the annual deaths in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/globalhealth/countries/tanzania/|title=Global health Tanzania}}</ref> The number of deaths has been declining since 2001 from 339/100,000 to 159/ 100,000 in 2013 however prevalence rates have increased from 4.3% to 5.3% and incidence has progressively decreased from 381/100,000 to 146/100,000 during the same time period.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aho.afro.who.int/profiles_information/images/c/c8/Tanzania-Statistical_Factsheet.pdf|title=Tanzania Statistical Factsheet 2016}}</ref>
===Malaria=== [[File:Saving Lives with SMS for Life.jpg|right|thumb|Malaria Clinic in Tanzania in partnership with [[Extreme Blue#Projects|SMS for Life]] program which organizes [[malaria vaccine]] delivery]] Malaria exists throughout the year and is predominantly due to [[P. falciparum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/countries/tza/en/|title=Tanzania, United Republic of}}</ref> The country had a decline of malaria cases over the years from 18.1% in 2001 to 9.7% in 2009 in under 5 year olds<ref>{{cite web|url=https://malariaworld.org/sites/default/files/mwjournal/article/MWJ2013_4_19.pdf|title=Towards malaria elimination and its implication for vector control, disease management and livelihoods in Tanzania|first=Leonard E.G. |last=Mboera |display-authors=etal}}</ref> and this is seen in the reduction of under 5 mortality rates which decreased from 165/ 100,000 in 1990 to 49/ 100,000 in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.unicef.org/publications/files/UNICEF_SOWC_2016.pdf|title=The State of the World's Children 2016}}</ref> This decrease in malaria prevalence is also shown in the Demographic and Health Survey and Malaria Indicator Survey 2015–16 (DHS-MIS 2015-16) with a 14% prevalence in 2015. This varied from Kagera's 41% and Geita's 38% to Zanzibar's <1%. It is also 18% in the rural area and urban 4% and also highest in the poorest quintile (23%) and lowest among the richest quintile (1%).
===Diarrhoeal diseases=== For the year 2014, 6% of the deaths in Tanzania were attributed to diarrhoeal diseases. It is imperative to reduce diarrheal diseases if the country is to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. In the [[UNICEF]] Pneumonia and Diarrhea Report 2016, there are strategies outlined for the low income countries to adopt in the fight against these two leading killer diseases.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://data.unicef.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/UNICEF-Pneumonia-Diarrhoea-report2016-web-version_final.pdf|title=UNICEF Pneumonia Diarrhea Disease Report 2016}}</ref>
===Lower respiratory tract infections=== This is listed as the second leading cause of mortality in Tanzania according to the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] Tanzania Global Health Facts. According to the [[DHS-MIS 2015-16|Demographic and Health Survey and Malaria Indicator Survey 2015–16]], there have been no changes over time of occurrence of LRTIs. However, the [[Expanded Program of Immunisation|EPI]] has included the [[pentavalent vaccine]] which protects against [[Haemophilus influenzae]], a common cause of [[pneumonia]].
===Tuberculosis=== There were 327/100,000 new cases of [[Tuberculosis|TB]] in 2014, up from 236/100,000 in 2001. The case detection rate dropped to 36% in 2014 from 68% in 2001 [[DHS-MIS 2015-16| Demographic and Health Survey and Malaria Indicator Survey 2015–16]]. TB deaths have increased from 17/100,000 in 2001 to 58/100,000 in 2014. (These cases were in HIV negative people.) Tuberculosis accounted for 5% of deaths in Tanzania in 2014.
===Non communicable diseases=== Tanzania has seen an increase of non communicable diseases as some of the leading causes of death. The major ones by contribution include: cancer 5%, ischemic heart disease 3% and stroke 3%.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/globalhealth/countries/tanzania/|title=Global health Tanzania}}</ref> The double burden of disease is causing an extra strain to the already fragile health system that is struggling to cope with the scourge of communicable diseases and high child and maternal mortality and morbidity.
== Occupational health == [[Tanzania]] is a [[United Republic]] of Former [[Tanganyika]] (currently referred to Tanganyika mainland) and Zanzibar. The estimated population has dramatically increased from 12.3 to 44.9 million people from 1967 to 2012 respectively (Figure 1. below),.<ref>{{cite web|last1=nbs|title=The United Republic of Tanzania: Population Distribution by Administrative Units: key findings: 2013.|url=http://nbs.go.tz/nbs/sensa/PDF/2012%20PHC%20POPULAR%20VERSION.pdf|website=nbs|accessdate=5 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305083544/http://nbs.go.tz/nbs/sensa/PDF/2012%20PHC%20POPULAR%20VERSION.pdf|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=}}</ref> The current working group (15– 64 years of age) of is estimated to be 52.2%. The National economy still depend mostly on agriculture that holds up to 40% of gross domestic product (GDP).<ref>{{cite web|last1=tzdpg|title=Ministry of Health Tanzania: Human Resource For Health Country Profile 2012/13.|url=http://www.tzdpg.or.tz/fileadmin/documents/dpg_internal/dpg_working_groups_clusters/cluster_2/health/Key_Sector_Documents/HRH_Documents/Final_Country_Profile_2013.pdf|website=tzdpg|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> Agriculture sector employs 76.5% of workforce in the Country; Industry sector (4.3%); and services (19.2%).<ref>{{cite web|last1=kpmg|title=Monitoring African Sovereign Risk: Tanzanian Snapshort: 2013 Quarter 3|url=http://www.kpmg.com/Africa/en/KPMG-in-Africa/Documents/2013%20Q3%20Snapshots/KPMG_Tanzania%202013Q3.pdf |website=kpmg|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref>
Figure 1:Tanzania population growth since 1967- 2012
[[File:Tanzania population growth trends.jpg|thumb|The figure shows the population growth trends for Tanzania from 1967 to 2012]]
===Occupational health in Tanzania perspective=== The country had been operating under Factories Ordinances Cap. 297 of 1950 that provided for [[occupational health and safety]] standards in the country. Through various sector reform programmes, The National established Occupational Health and Safety Authority under The Executive Agency Act No. 30 of 1997 which become officially operational late 2001.<ref>{{cite web|title=Occupational Safety and Health Authority- Tanzania: Background|url=http://osha.go.tz/index.php/about-osha/background|website=OSHA-TANZANIA|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909014147/http://osha.go.tz/index.php/about-osha/background|archivedate=2015-09-09|df=}}</ref> Moreover, in 2003 the Occupational Health and Safety Act No. 5 was enacted giving the authority mandatory objectives of providing the safety, health and welfare of persons at work in factories and other places of work; to provide for the protection of persons other than persons at work against hazards to health and safety arising out of or in connection with activities of persons at work.<ref>{{cite web|title=The United Republic of Tanzania: The Occupational Health and safety Act No.5 of 2013|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---ed_protect/---protrav/---ilo_aids/documents/legaldocument/wcms_151291.pdf|website=ILO|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref>
Other initiatives the country has gone through includes incorporation of [[occupational health]] and safety matters in other Principal legislation such as The Tropical Pesticides Research Institute Act of 1979; The Pharmaceuticals and Poison Act of 1978; The Atomic Energy Act of 2003, The Industrial and Consumer Chemicals Act of 1985;<ref>{{cite web|title=Occupational safety and health: Tanzania Country profile, 2004|url=//www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---ed_protect/---protrav/---safework/documents/policy/wcms_187634.pdf|website=ILO|accessdate=5 September 2015}}</ref> The Mining Act of 2010 and Employment and labour relation Act No.6 of 2004 with subsequent establishment of Labour Court (being part of The High Court of Tanzania).
In 2008 another important step was made – the establishment of Workers' Compensation Fund through Workers Compensation Act No. 20 of 2008<ref>{{cite web|title=The United Republic of Tanzania: Workers Compensation Act No. 20 of 2008|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---ed_protect/---protrav/---ilo_aids/documents/legaldocument/wcms_125593.pdf|website=ILO|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref> with objectives of providing for compensation to employees for disablement of death caused by or result from injuries or diseases sustained or contracted in the course of employment; to establish Fund for administration and regulation of workers compensation and to provide for related matter.
The [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO), estimates that more than 2.3 million people die of work-related accidents and diseases every year and 317 million accidents annually occur due to workplace hazards. The figures further explain that out of 2.34 million occupational fatalities every year; only 321,000 are due to accidents, the remaining 2.02 million deaths are caused by various types of work-related diseases, which correspond to a daily average between 5,500 up to 6,000 deaths.<ref>{{cite web|title=International Labour Organization: Health and Safety at Work: facts and Figures|url=http://www.ilo.org/global/about-the-ilo/media-centre/issue-briefs/WCMS_206117/lang--en/index.htm|website=ILO|accessdate=7 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150913202847/http://ilo.org/global/about-the-ilo/media-centre/issue-briefs/WCMS_206117/lang--en/index.htm|archivedate=13 September 2015|df=}}</ref>
===Occupational injuries=== Every individual worker needs good working environment that is safe and free from any kind of life - threatening hazards. This may be possible where most if not all health risks are identified at workplace and correct measures are put in place and adhered by all workers around. Mining sector is fast growing in a country and significant number of workers both in conventional and small scale mining are employed. The sector contributes up to 40% of country's export<ref>{{cite web|last1=tcme|title=Tanzania chamber of Minerals and Energy: Mining in Tanzania: Overview of mining sector|url=http://www.tcme.or.tz/mining-in-tanzania/industry-overview/|website=tcme|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> and it was estimated to contribute up to 7.7% of national GDP by end of 2015.
Status of [[occupational accidents]] and [[injuries]] varies considerably between different sources. It is estimated that in [[mining]]/quarry, the injury rate is 17 per 1,000 workers whereas [[Industry]] sector is responsible for 10.1% of total occupational accidents, 9.6% of [[Death|fatalities]], 12.2% of partial disabilities and about 7.4% of temporary disability and the [[injury rate]] is 9.9 per 1,000 workers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=TCRB|title=Contractors registration Board: Status of Occupational Health and Safety in Tanzanian Construction Industry|url=http://www.crbtz.org/documents/newsletter/dec2009/ohsstatus.pdf|website=tcrb|accessdate=5 September 2015}}</ref>
Report from National Audit office (NAO) showed that [[construction]]/building industry had highest Fatality rate of 23.7% followed by [[Transport]] and mining/quarrying that had 20.6% and 20.5 respectively (table 1 below).<ref>{{cite web|last1=NAO|title=The United Republic of Tanzania, National Audit Office. A Performance Audit Report on The Management of Occupational Health and Safety in Tanzania, 2013|url=http://www.nao.go.tz/?wpfb_dl=98|website=nao.go.tz|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> Injuries in transport sector is another life-threatening risk that continues to claim lives of people especially motorcyclist and public transport (buses). however the major challenge in these information is validity and reliability as the reporting and data keeping system in Tanzania is not well coordinated.
Table 1: Fatality Rate sectorwise {| class="Fatality rate sector-wise" |- ! Sector !!Total employees !! Number of Fatal Injuries !!Fatality rate (%) |- | Agriculture, forestry, Fishing || 13,890,054 || 16 || 0.12 |- | Mining and quarrying || 29,223 || 6 || 20.53 |- | Commerce and distribution || 2,486,818 || 12 || 0.48 |- | Manufacturing|| 245,449 || 28 || 11.41 |- | Construction/building || 151,690 || 36|| 23.73 |- | Transport || 111,671 || 23 || 20.61 |- | Total|| 16,914,805 || 121 || |}Source: NAO report- Performance Audit Report on the Management of Occupational Health and Safety in Tanzania, 2013.
The presented information may be challenged by several other factors as reporting system is not well functional. There were a total of 6,599 registered workplaces equivalent to 24% of eligible workplaces. This challenges is a challenge to The Authority dealing with Occupational safety and Health in Tanzania. Accelerated development as a result of new large discoveries and investments in [[Oil]], [[gas]] and [[Uranium]] and expected spill - over effects calls for serious investments in this areas as more workers will be involved and exposure to [[occupational hazards]] will need serious interventions.

[[Image:Iami logo original.GIF|right|thumb|225px|IAMI logo]] The '''Indian Association for Medical Informatics''' ('''IAMI''') is a [[professional society]] that plays a role in promoting and furthering the application of [[Health informatics|informatics]] in the fields of [[healthcare]], [[bioscience]] and [[medicine]] in [[India]]. It was established in 1993.
== Goals and objectives == The objectives<ref>[http://www.iami.org.in/objectives.asp]</ref> of the IAMI are to sensitize the Indian [[medical]] community to the benefits of [[Information Technology]] (IT), bring about awareness and ensure greater utilization of IT in healthcare facilities across the length and breadth of India. The IAMI also aims to provide necessary assistance and guidance to other organizations to implement and reap the benefits of IT for health care. It supports introduction of [[computer literacy]] along with medical education, development of computerized as well as medical [[Digital library|digital libraries]], access to [[information]] and creation of [[database]]s. IAMI emphasizes research and development of medical informatics as an independent [[Academic discipline|discipline]]. It provides various communication and interaction channels among its members by means of e-groups and through publication of a [[Academic journal|scholarly journal]].
== Affiliation == It is the Indian National Member at [[IMIA]].<ref>[http://www.imia.org/action.lasso?-database=organizations.fp5&-response=member_profile.html&-layout=CGI&-sortField=country&-sortOrder=ascending&-op=bw&type=national&-maxRecords=1&-skipRecords=18&-search]</ref>
== History == IAMI was registered in September 1993 with its Registered Office being the Department of Clinical Pharmacology, Nizam's Institute of Medical Sciences, in [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]], India.
It has been organising a conference every two years on roles and applications of informatics in medicine, health and allied fields in various states of India.
The first biennial conference was held in 1995 at Hyderabad.
The second conference was held in 1997 at [[Indian Institute of Science]], [[Bangalore]].
The third conference in 1999 in Hyderabad was postponed due to natural calamities. A workshop was also held at NIMS in lieu later.
The third conference was held in 2001 in New Delhi.
The fourth conference was held in 2003 at PGIMER, [[Chandigarh]].
A mid-conference was held in 2004 at the [[South Eastern Railway (India)|South-Eastern Railways]] Hospital, [[Kolkata]].
The fifth conference was held in 2005 at Sri Guru Ram Das Institute of Medical Sciences in [[Amritsar]].
IAMI has conducted many beginners' courses for [[Physician|doctor]]s, [[nurse]]s, [[paramedic]]al [[personnel]] and [[computer]] [[professional class]]. This enabled the association in enrolling many [[hospital]]s, [[institute]]s and [[organization]]s as Institutional Life Members. It is aiming at making Medical Informatics as one of the elective subjects in the UG curriculum for all medical colleges in India and to get academic credits from the [[Medical Council of India]] and other autonomous bodies under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India), [[Government of India]] for all the delegates participating in the [[Academic conference|conferences]], [[seminar]]s and [[workshop]]s organized by the association.
In 2001, it started a discussion group for medical informatics. Which has now grown into the de facto information source for medical informatics-related activities in India for its members as well as non-members. Its active members include almost everyone in the medical informatics scene of India. IAMI got its own website in 2002. Its ''Indian Journal of Medical Informatics'' (''IJMI'', {{ISSN|0973-0397}}) was started in May 2004.<ref>[http://www.iami.org.in/history.asp]</ref>
== Membership == IAMI membership consists of Personal, Institutional and Honorary Members.
Many of its key office bearers are part of several [[Government of India]] (GOI) initiatives in the areas of telemedicine, especially in the area of development of standards and guidelines for the practice of [[telemedicine]], [[E-learning|online medical education]] and [[electronic medical record]]s or [[electronic health record]]s.
== Journal == It produces the [[scientific journal]] called ''Indian Journal of Medical Informatics''.<ref>[http://www.medicalinformatics.org.in/ojs/index.php/ijmi/index]</ref>
==Discussion group== Members of the association have an active discussion group<ref>[https://groups.google.com/group/iami_gen]</ref> where healthcare IT enthusiasts discuss topics of their interest. Several discussion threads run in parallel. There is also a "topic of the month" which is the main focus of the discussion.
==See also== * [[Medical informatics]]
== External links == *[http://www.iami.org.in/ IAMI] *[http://www.iami.org.in/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=96&Itemid=185 List of Mentors in Healthcare Informatics] *[http://www.ijmi.org/index.php/ijmi ''Indian Journal of Medical Informatics'' (''IJMI'')]

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Irish Lumper potato.png|thumb|right|An Irish Lumper potato]] --> {{Infobox cultivar | name = ''Potato'' 'Irish Lumper' | image = | image_caption = | species = ''[[Potato|Solanum tuberosum]]'' | genus = ''[[Solanum]]'' | cultivar = 'Irish Lumper' | origin = }} The '''Irish Lumper''' is a varietal white [[potato]] of historic interest. It has been identified as the variety of potato whose widespread cultivation throughout [[Ireland]], prior to the 1840s, is implicated in the [[Great Famine (Ireland)|Irish Great Famine]] in which an estimated 1 million died.<ref name="IrishCentral">{{cite web
| last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Great Famine potato makes a comeback after 170 years | work = | publisher = IrishCentral | date = 3 March 2013 | url = http://www.irishcentral.com/news/Great-Famine-potato-makes-a-comeback-after-170-years-194635321.html | doi = | accessdate = 5 March 2013 }}</ref>
== Agricultural features == The 'Irish Lumper' is noted for its ability to flourish on [[Lazy bed|garden beds]] that are poor in nutrients, wet-footed, or both. Until the 1840s, it was closely adapted to growing conditions in [[Ireland]], particularly [[West Region, Ireland|western Ireland]]. The [[Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food]] of Ireland noted that the Lumper was a "very old variety, and ... probably well known when first recorded by Dutton (1808) in his Agricultural Survey of County Clare. ... It was described by Andrews (1835) as a 'coarse species' and was recommended by Howden (1837) as stock feed due to its enormous yield."<ref name="daff">{{cite book|title=Potato Varieties of Historical Interest in Ireland|date=2008|publisher=[[Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food]]|location=Dublin, Ireland|isbn=978-0-9565715-0-2|pages=45–46|url=http://www.agriculture.gov.ie/media/migration/farmingsectors/crops/seedcertification/topspotatocentre/PotatoBook010610.pdf|accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref>
In the 1840s, infestations of ''[[Phytophthora infestans]]'' devastated a series of potato harvests, leading to widespread [[famine]] and [[Irish diaspora|emigration]]. The cumulative effects of both catastrophes lowered Ireland's total population by approximately 2 million, of which approximately 1 million were fatalities.
After almost disappearing from cultivation, the 'Irish Lumper' was regrown, starting in 2008, by Michael McKillop of [[County Antrim]] for harvest sale as an [[heirloom plant|heirloom varietal]].<ref name=pope>{{cite news|last=Pope|first=Conor|title=Great Famine spud returns after almost 170 years|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/frontpage/2013/0302/1224330699102.html|accessdate=16 April 2014|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|date=2 March 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302173952/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/frontpage/2013/0302/1224330699102.html|archivedate=2 March 2013}}</ref>
== Culinary use == The 'Irish Lumper' has been characterized as a "wet, nasty, knobbly old potato." Its texture upon boiling is described as more "waxy" than "floury", indicating a starch content on the lower side of that typical for white potatoes.<ref name=dailyspud>{{cite web|last=Cox|first=Aoife|title=Spud Sunday: Return of the Lumper|url=http://www.thedailyspud.com/2013/03/11/lumper-potatoes/|work=The Daily Spud|accessdate=16 April 2014|date=11 March 2013}}</ref>
== Educational use == Schools in Ireland are starting to cultivate the 'Irish Lumper' as a project of historical education. The Lumpers are cultivated in [[Raised-bed gardening|raised garden beds]], as their ancestors were in the 1840s.<ref name=BelfastTelegraph>{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Famine's lost potato: knobbly Lumper unites schoolchildren|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/education/famines-lost-potato-knobbly-lumper-unites-schoolchildren-30174685.html|work=[[The Belfast Telegraph]]|accessdate=18 April 2014|date=11 April 2014}}</ref>

'''Iron oxide adsorption''' is a [[water treatment]] process that is used to remove [[arsenic]] from [[drinking water]]. Arsenic is a common natural contaminant of [[Water well|well]] water and is highly [[carcinogenic]]. [[Iron oxide]] [[adsorption]] treatment for arsenic in groundwater is a commonly practiced removal process which involves the chemical treatment of arsenic species such that they adsorb onto iron oxides and [[flocculation|create larger particles]] that may be [[filtration|filtered]] out of the water stream. The addition of [[ferric chloride]], FeCl3, to well water immediately after the well at the influent to the treatment plant creates ferric hydroxide, Fe(OH)3, and hydrochloric acid, HCl. :3H2O + FeCl3 → Fe(OH)3 + 3HCl Fe(OH)3 in water is a strong adsorbent of arsenate, As(V), provided that the pH is low. HCl lowers pH, assuring arsenic adsorption, and the disassociated chlorine oxidizes iron in solution from Fe+2 to Fe+3, which then may bond with hydroxide ions, OH−, thus creating more adsorbent. This adjustment also lowers the pH of the well water, decreasing alkalinity and allowing more cationic species such Fe(+) or As(+) as to exist freely within the flow. Low pH also decreases the solubility of some iron and arsenic species as well as increasing the adsorptive reactivity of arsenate, As(V). Additional oxidation of Fe+2 to Fe+3, also referred to as iron(II) and iron(III), is induced by the addition of [[sodium hypochlorite]], NaOCl, at the well head. NaOCl is usually added for [[disinfection]] although it may be used in this case towards the objectives of a distribution system free chlorine residual of 1 mg/L ''and'' the oxidation of aqueous As(III) to As(V), and aqueous iron Fe+2 to Fe+3, which will bond with hydroxide for further adsorption. The filter media usually consists of [[anthracite]], iron-manganese oxidizing sand, and [[garnet]] sand over support [[gravel]].{{cite | title = Chemistry of Water Treatment| date = 1998 | author = Faust, Aly | publisher = CRC Press}} == References ==

The '''King Edward VII Memorial Hospital''' in [[Stanley, Falkland Islands]] is the base for the Falkland Islands Government Health Service. There is a hospital of the same name in [[Bermuda Hospitals Board|Bermuda]].
Health services are funded by fish licence revenue and by income tax. They are entirely free at the point of delivery to Islands residents and to British residents under a [[reciprocal health agreement]]. In 2003 the provision of the service cost £950 per head of population per year, similar to the cost in the UK. Services are provided to about 3000 residents. The military base provides its own health care, but makes use of the hospital facilities as necessary.
This is the only hospital on the Islands. All the islands' medical, dental and community health services are based there. There are 18 acute beds, one maternity bed, a single bedded isolation unit, a two bedded intensive care unit and seven long-stay nursing beds.<ref>{{cite web|title=Health|url=http://www.falklands.gov.fk/our-people/daily-life/health-services/|website=Falklands Islands Government|accessdate=18 October 2015}}</ref> It was rebuilt in 1987 after a fire destroyed the earlier wooden building. The range of equipment and facilities is surprisingly comprehensive, as it has to be almost entirely self-sufficient and takes referrals from [[Tristan da Cunha]], [[South Georgia Island|South Georgia]], and [[Antarctica]]. Before 1982 medical services on the islands were very basic, but there has been considerable investment since. [[Colorectal cancer]] was particularly common on the islands, linked to a very unusual gene mutation and a three-yearly colorectal screening programme was introduced in 1997. It reached 99% of the population and appears to have virtually eliminated colorectal carcinoma.
There are four full-time GPs and one part-time. A consultant surgeon and consultant anaesthetist do four month tours of duty on the Islands. A radiographer, a biomedical scientist, and a dental hygienist are seconded from [[NHS trust]]s. There are 2 practice nurses, a part-time nurse practitioner, 2 casualty nurses, ward nurses and healthcare assistants. The GPs have to provide all medical care apart from surgery or anaesthesia, supported by visiting specialists, mostly from the UK who help to keep them up to date. Consultations take place by telephone for patients in remote locations. There are weekly visits by GPs to patients outside Stanley. There are three midwives, and about 30 babies are born each year. A medicine chest is provided for these patients and replenished as necessary.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Diggle|first1=R|title=Medicine in the Falkland Islands|journal=Postgraduate Medical Journal|date=2003|volume=79|issue=927|page=3|url=http://pmj.bmj.com/content/79/927/3.full|accessdate=18 October 2015|doi=10.1136/pmj.79.927.3|pmc=1742590}}</ref> Patients, or doctors, can be transported by the [[Falkland Islands Government Air Service]] if necessary. Serious emergencies are taken to Chile.
Dr Constant Ndjapa-Ndamkou, the chief medical officer. They use [[EMIS Health|EMIS software]] for medical records.<ref>{{cite news|title=Life as a GP in the Falkland Islands|url=http://www.gponline.com/life-gp-falkland-islands/article/1170529|accessdate=18 October 2015|publisher=GP Online|date=14 February 2013}}</ref>
Sir [[Jack Hayward]] contributed to the repairs of the hospital after the 1982 [[Falklands War]].

The largest state-owned hospital in [[Uganda]] is [[Mulago Hospital]] in [[Kampala]] with around 1,500 beds. It was built in 1962.<ref>{{cite web | first=Chris | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Time-bomb--The-inside-story-of-Mulago-hospital-s-troubles/-/688334/1669688/-/13xumh5/-/index.html | title=Time bomb: The inside story of Mulago hospital's troubles | last=Obore | accessdate=5 April 2016 | date=20 January 2013 | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala}}</ref>
[[Ian Clarke (physician)|Ian Clarke]], a physician and missionary from [[Northern Ireland]],<ref name="Dive">{{cite web|accessdate=8 May 2016| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/02/world/africa/02uganda.html?_r=0 | title=Of Irish Soil and Ugandan Politics |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |location=New York City |last=Josh Kron |first=and Jeffrey Gettleman | date=1 March 2011}}</ref> built the 200-bed [[International Hospital Kampala]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.observer.ug/business/38-business/38771-mauritius-firm-takes-over-international-medical-group | title=Mauritius firm takes over International Medical Group |last=Mugalu |first=Moses |newspaper=[[The Observer (Uganda)]] | location=Kampala |accessdate=8 May 2016 |date=15 July 2015}}</ref> which was the first [[International Organization for Standardization]]-certified hospital in the country.<ref>{{cite web |title=Ian Clarke gets ISO certification |first=Jude | accessdate=5 May 2016 |newspaper=[[New Vision]] | last=Etyang |url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1132408/ian-clarke-iso-certification | date=24 January 2005 | location=Uganda}}</ref>
According to a published report in 2009, the distribution of healthcare facilities and funding heavily favored urban centers, with 70 percent of physicians and 40 percent of nurses and midwives based in urban areas, where they served only 12 percent of Uganda's population.<ref>{{cite web |title=Healthcare a major challenge for Uganda |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |first=Annie | url=https://www.theguardian.com/katine/2009/apr/01/healthcare-in-uganda |accessdate=5 May 2016 |date=31 March 2009 |last=Kelly | location=London}}</ref>
==National referral hospitals== * [[Butabika National Referral Hospital]]<ref>{{cite web | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | date=16 September 2013 | first=Farahani |access-date=4 July 2015 |location=Kampala | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Butabika-hospital-decries-shortage-of-psychiatrists/-/688334/1993670/-/uxgt2b/-/index.html | title=Butabika hospital decries dhortage of psychiatrists | last=Mukisa}}</ref> * [[Mulago National Referral Hospital]]<ref>{{cite web | accessdate=3 July 2015 | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Mulago-hospital-renovation-starts/-/688334/2481588/-/gbe7ohz/-/index.html | date=11 October 2014 | title=Mulago hospital renovation starts | first=Agatha | last=Ayebazibwe | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala}}</ref>
